Investors moved the chains for Electronic Arts (EA) on Tuesday as the stock reached an all-time high on prospects for the company's "Madden NFL 17" football video game.EA stock rose 1% to 82.31 on the stock market today. Earlier, EA stock hit a record high of 82.61. EA broke out of a flat base with an 80.09 buy point last Thursday.EA's move happened as the Nasdaq composite also hit an intraday record high Tuesday. Other video game stocks rose as well, including Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).Activision climbed 1.3% to 40.64, and Take-Two rose 2.3% to 42.25 on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Software-Gaming group is ranked No. 26 out of 197 industry groups. Two companies from the group, NetEase and Activision Blizzard, are on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.On Tuesday, Electronic Arts released "Madden NFL 17," the latest in its long-running pro football game series. It can be played on Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 3 and 4 consoles and on Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox 360 and Xbox One consoles.In a research report Monday, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating and price target of 88 on EA stock. He said his sales estimates for the new Madden game could be "overly conservative.""Madden NFL 17" has a current average Metacritic rating of 83.5, which is in line with last year's game (84 rating) but ahead of the 10-year average of 81.9, he said."Given solid scores and a larger next-gen console base, it appears our Madden estimate for 5.5 million units through fiscal 2017 (flat year over year), may prove conservative," Olson said. "Overall, EA appears poised to benefit from continued growth of the hardware installed base, as the company has a strong slate of titles through second-half calendar 2016, highlighted by 'Battlefield 1' and 'Titanfall 2' in October."RELATED:Most-Anticipated Video Game Is Out Of This World.

The Relative Strength (RS) Rating for Changyou.com (CYOU) moved into a higher percentile Thursday, as it got a lift from 64 to 74. Over 100 years of market history shows that the market's biggest winners often have an RS Rating north of 80 as they launch their largest price moves. See if Changyou.com can continue to rebound and clear that threshold. See How IBD Helps You Make More Money In StocksChangyou.com is working on a consolidation with a 44.65 entry. See if the stock can clear the breakout price in volume at least 40% higher than normal. Earnings growth dropped in the most recent report from 68% to -110%. But sales moved higher, from 16% to 22%. Changyou.com holds the No. 8 rank among its peers in the Computer Software-Gaming industry group. Shares of video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) soared Wednesday after the maker of "Grand Theft Auto" reported better-than-expected September-quarter results and guided higher for the holiday sales quarter.XTake-Two shares jumped 10.6% to close at 117.65 on the stock market today. In intraday trading, Take-Two hit a record high of 120.Take-Two delivered earnings per share of $1.09, up 65% year over year, on sales of $577 million, up 20%, on an adjusted basis, in its fiscal second quarter ended Sept. 30. Analysts expected 74 cents and $515 million.Its September-quarter upside was driven by the continued success of "Grand Theft Auto 5" and "Grand Theft Auto Online," as well as basketball simulation game "NBA 2K18."For the December quarter, Take-Two expects to earn an adjusted 89 cents a share on sales of $635 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Wall Street was modeling 82 cents and $545 million.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software has an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of 99. For more analysis on Take-Two and its peers, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two stock received at least nine price-target hikes from Wall Street firms post-earnings. Of those firms, six have buy ratings on the stock and three are neutral.The most bullish of the group was KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Evan Wingren. He reiterated his overweight rating on the stock and upped his price target to 144 from 119.He sees strong prospects for the company next year, driven by "Red Dead Redemption 2" and "Borderlands 3."Baird analyst Colin Sebastian turned positive on Take-Two, upgrading the stock to outperform from neutral and raising his price target to 137 from 90."The company is demonstrating faster growth and better operating discipline than we expected with the transition to digital (distribution), with essentially none of the expected decay in GTA usage," he said in a report.Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter maintained his neutral rating on the stock, but upped his price target to 95 from 66."Take-Two has consistently delivered upside to guidance and consensus, making its shares attractive over the near term," Pachter said in a report. "We remain unwilling to recommend the shares due to an unclear long-term release slate."Elsewhere in the video game sector, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) said its new game "Call of Duty: WWII" surpassed $500 million in worldwide sales in its first three days of availability. The World War II-themed combat game was released on Friday.Activision said its latest "Call of Duty" game sold twice as many units at launch as last year's edition, "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare."The game's opening-weekend sales were bigger than the theatrical box office openings of "Thor: Ragnarok" and "Wonder Woman" combined, Activision said in a news release.Activision stock surged nearly 6% to close at 64.55.RELATED:Take-Two Interactive Software Beats Sales Target, Guides Higher

A survey of current-generation console video game players picked "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI) as the most-anticipated new video game."Infinite Warfare," the latest in the long-running "Call of Duty" series, is a first-person shooter game set in the distant future that takes place on Earth, in space and across the solar system. It is scheduled for release on Nov. 4 for Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Windows PCs.Piper Jaffray, in a research report Monday, said it surveyed over 100 PS4 and Xbox One owners to gauge purchase intent for new video games.When asked about upcoming games, 33% were "most excited" to purchase "Infinite Warfare." That compares with a year-ago survey where 27% of respondents chose "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," the previous installment in the series, as their most-anticipated game.Piper analyst Michael Olson said the strong demand for "Infinite Warfare" alleviates concerns about possible "franchise fatigue."IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Software Gaming group ranks No. 54 out of 197 industry groups. China's NetEase has the group's highest Composite Rating of 99. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.A close second among most-anticipated new games is "Battlefield 1" from Electronic Arts (EA). "Battlefield 1" is a first-person shooter game set during World War I. It is scheduled for release on Oct. 21 for PS4, Xbox One and Windows PCs."Battlefield 1" was the most-anticipated game for 26% of survey respondents, Olson said.Rounding out the top five most-desired new games were "Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands" from Ubisoft at 15%, and "Gears of War 4" from Microsoft and "The Last Guardian" from Sony, each with 10%."Ghost Recon Wildlands" is due for release on March 7. "Gears of Wars" is set to launch on Oct. 11 and "The Last Guardian" will hit shelves on Oct. 25.The survey showed lackluster demand for "Mafia 3" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO). Just 6% of respondents said it was the game they were most-excited about buying, Olson said.Olson has overweight ratings on Activision, EA and Take-Two with price targets of 46, 88 and 45, respectively.Activision stock rose 0.35% to 104.50 on the stock market today. EA fell 0.3% to 81.49. Take-Two climbed 0.8% to 41.29.RELATED:

Heading into the holiday season, video game makers are showing very mixed action. Two leaders are showing strong price movement, while two others are biding their time in base-building mode. X  The Computer Software-Gaming industry has long been a top-tier group. It is currently ranked No. 14 out of 197 groups. Leading stock Take-Two Interactive Software[ticker…

Video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) won analyst praise Friday, a day after they each reported better-than-expected results for the June quarter.Activision stock fell 0.7% to 40.56 on the stock market today. Earlier Friday, however, it had risen nearly 4%. It reached a record high of 43.05 on July 13.Take-Two stock rose 2% to 41.37. Early in the session it hit a new all-time high of 42.73.Both companies are benefiting from the console upgrade cycle and the shift to digital game downloads.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, while Take-Two has a rating of 76. Both companies are in the upper quarter of performance for stocks in key metrics over the last 12 months. For more information, check out the IBD Stock Checkup.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision earned 54 cents a share excluding items, up 315% year over year, on sales of $1.61 billion, up 112%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 42 cents and $1.46 billion.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Activision earned 17 cents a share, down 41%, in Q2. GAAP earnings per share include the impact of stock-based compensation and expenses related to Activision's purchase of King Digital Entertainment. Its sales under GAAP accounting rose 50% to $1.57 billion. GAAP sales exclude revenue deferrals from online games.Activision also increased its guidance for full-year revenue and EPS. It now expects to earn $1.90 a share on sales of $6.48 billion, vs. Wall Street estimates for $1.88 EPS and $6.35 billion in sales.Activision credited its strong Q2 performance to the hit new video game "Overwatch" and the continued success of its "Call of Duty" and "Candy Crush" game franchises.At least seven analysts raised their price targets on Activision stock following the company's earnings beat.Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz hiked his price target to 55 from 45 and kept his buy rating.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter increased his price target to 48 from 43 and stuck with his outperform rating.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson raised his price target to 46 from 42 and maintained his overweight rating.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian upped his price target to 46 from 43 and reiterated his outperform rating.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz lifted his price target to 45 from 44 and stayed with his outperform rating.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson beefed up his price target to 45 from 43 and held on to his overweight rating.UBS analyst Eric Sheridan maintained his buy rating on Activision but raised his price target to 52 from 50.New York-based Take-Two lost 46 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of 81 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter ended June 30. Sales rose 13% to nearly $312 million in Q1.Take-Two said "Grand Theft Auto 5," "Grand Theft Auto Online," "NBA 2K16" and "Battleborn" were the largest contributors to its Q1 sales growth.Analysts were more cautious on Take-Two given unknowns about its upcoming games. But the stock still earned price target increases from at least five analysts.Baird's Sebastian increased his price target to 43 from 37, but reiterated his neutral rating.Wedbush's Pachter upped his price target to 41.50 from 32, but also maintained his neutral rating.Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey raised his price target on Take-Two to 45.92 from 42.92 and maintained his buy rating.Cowen's Creutz raised his price target to 45 from 43 and kept his outperform rating.Piper Jaffray's Olson upped his price target to 45 from 40 and kept his overweight rating.Olson sees continued strength in "Grand Theft Auto Online" and expects Take-Two to release a new game in its "Red Dead" Western series next year.

Electronic Arts (EA) stock fell Wednesday after the video game publisher forecast lower-than-expected sales for the holiday quarter, but bullish analysts think the company is being conservative with its guidance.EA shares fell 4.3% to close at 114.47 on the stock market today.Late Tuesday, Electronic Arts said it expects adjusted revenue of $2 billion in its fiscal third quarter ending Dec. 31. Analysts had been expecting $2.06 billion.EA also reported September-quarter results, with earnings beating expectations on in-line sales. The Redwood City, Calif.-based company earned an adjusted 62 cents a share, up 17% year over year, on adjusted sales of $1.18 billion, up 7%. Analysts expected 54 cents and $1.18 billion."We believe management is trying to keep estimates conservative ahead of the launch of 'Star Wars Battlefront 2' on Nov. 17," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a note to clients. "Star Wars Battlefront 2" is EA's big holiday game release, but scuttlebutt on the title has been mixed.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts has an IBD Composite Rating of 98, meaning it has outperformed 98% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more analysis of EA stock, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Olson reiterated his overweight rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 130 from 128.Jefferies analyst Timothy O'Shea raised his price target on EA to 138 from 135 and kept his buy rating."Key holiday launch 'Star Wars Battlefront 2' is the biggest swing factor for fiscal 2018," O'Shea said in a report. "If Star Wars can encourage users to spend real money on virtual goods (like FIFA) the game could drive meaningful upside to fiscal 2018 and 2019 EPS, but this is not a certainty. Looking past the holidays we remain bullish as EA is benefiting from a multitude of powerful tailwinds including more in-game spending, more downloads, and more mobile."Stifel analyst Drew Crum was satisfied with EA's earnings report. He maintained his buy rating and price target of 127."Overall we thought this was another solid update for EA, reaffirming our positive stance on the shares," he said in a report.Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz also liked what he saw and kept his outperform rating and price target of 130 on the stock."Management took a positive tone and highlighted strength from its sports titles (FIFA and Madden) and encouraging user engagement trends," Uerkwitz said in a report.Other analysts were unconvinced.CFRA analyst Scott Kessler reiterated his sell rating on EA, but upped his price target to 108 from 106."We see considerable competition and an excessive valuation," he said in a note.Elsewhere in the video game sector, Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) received a price-target hike. Brokerage Stifel upped its target on Take-Two to 122 from 105 and kept its buy rating.Take-Two is scheduled to report fiscal second-quarter results after the market close Nov. 7. The game publisher is likely to get a boost from sales of "NBA 2K18" and "Grand Theft Auto," he said.Take-Two shares slipped by 9 cents to finish at 110.56.RELATED:Electronic Arts Guides To Holiday Sales Below ViewsTake-Two Scores New High On Price-Target Hike; NetEase Downgraded

Three top video game publishers with stocks that recently hit record highs are set to report quarterly earnings this week. Investors want to see whether the shares will advance to the next level, or if it's game over.Electronic Arts (EA) is up first, reporting fiscal-first-quarter results after the market close Tuesday. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) follow on Thursday with their own June-quarter results.Electronic Arts notched an all-time high of 79.99 on July 12. EA stock rose 0.4% to 76.63 on the stock market today.Activision Blizzard scored its record high of 43.05 on July 13. Activision fell 0.2% to 40.07 Monday.Take-Two Interactive hit its all-time high of 41.71 on July 12. The stock rose 0.3% to 40.29 on Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Of the three big video game publishers, Electronic Arts has the best IBD Composite Rating. Its 92 rating means it has outperformed 92% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more details, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Electronic Artsto lose 2 cents a share excluding items on sales of $651 million, down 6% year over year, in fiscal Q1. On a fully reported basis, EA expects to earn $1.32 a share.Complicating the earnings reports this quarter is that EA, Activision and some other companies have switched to GAAP financial reporting to comply with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules.Last month, Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said the changes could cause some "headline confusion" for video game stocks.For Q2, Activision is expected to earn 42 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.46 billion. Earnings per share are seen jumping 223% year over year with sales up 92%, thanks to its hit video game "Overwatch." On a fully reported basis, Activision's EPS is seen dipping 17% to 24 cents.For its fiscal Q1, Take-Two is seen posting revenue of $259 million, down 29%, during a quiet game release period. It is expected to post earnings per share of 16 cents on a fully reported basis, but a loss of 30 cents a share on a non-GAAP basis.RELATED:Activision's 'Overwatch' Leads Soft Month For Video Game Sales

Consumer stocks led gains in the stock market Wednesday as major stock indexes were modestly higher and small-caps found some footing.XThe Nasdaq composite added 0.3%, with strength in gaming software, fiber optics and other software and computing industry groups aiding its leading performance.The S&P 500 added 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose a fraction. The Russell 2000 rose 0.2% as the small-cap benchmark found support at its 50-day moving average. Market volume was lower than yesterday's totals, according to early data.The consumer rally was evident in some other leading groups Wednesday. Dairy products, meat products, consumer electronics retail, home furnishings, and footwear were some of the top 12 groups in today's trading.Gaming software led after Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) surged more than 10% to a record high on strong earnings and improved guidance for the holiday quarter.There was good news for casinos after MGM Resorts (MGM) beat revenue estimates and matched profit views with its third-quarter report. In an encouraging sign for the industry, MGM said cancellations since last month's massive shooting in Las Vegas have largely ended and bookings are near normal levels.The gunman, who killed nearly 60 people, fired weapons from a room in MGM's Mandalay Bay hotel. MGM shares closed 5% higher.Some other consumer-oriented groups lagged, however. Soft drinks, periodicals, telecom services and tobacco were down more than 1%.Weibo (WB) broke out of a double-bottom base, rising past the 105.60 buy point in more than double its average volume. On Tuesday, the Chinese Twitter-like service beat profit expectations. Adjusted earnings of 51 cents a share more than doubled from the year-ago period.Splunk (SPLK) broke out of a cup without handle with a 69.71 entry. Volume was about 50% more than average, a good sign. But the stock has made little gains from its past three breakout bids. The data analytics software company is announcing results for the October-ending quarter on Nov. 16.Breakouts continued among real estate investment trusts, and Four Corners Property Trust (FCPT) was the latest to fit the bill. The owner of restaurant properties climbed above the 26.04 entry of a flat base in about average volume.RELATED:China Web Firms Sina, Weibo, Autohome Top Third-Quarter ViewsMGM Resorts Rallies As Bookings Rebound After Shooting

Monster Beverage (MNST), Priceline (PCLN), Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) reported quarterly earnings after the close.Estimates: Wall Street expects the energy-drink giant to report a 30% EPS increase to $1.03, with sales up 16% to $804.24 million.Results: Monster Beverage earned 99 cents, up 25% but below views. Sales rose 19% to $827.5 million, although the strong dollar hurt results.Monster also announced a $250 million buyback program.Monster shares rose 1% in after-hours action. Monster shares closed up 0.5% to 158.59 on the stock market today, finding support at their 50-day line intraday. The stock remains in buy range after breaking out in June.Estimates: The video game publisher's EPS is expected to surge 223% to 42 cents, with sales jumping 91% to $1.45 billion.Results: EPS was 45 cents, up 246%. Sales rose 50 to $1.57 billion.The results were helped by the multiplayer shooter game "Overwatch" and and the acquisition of King Digital Entertainment, the maker of "Candy Crush.""With Overwatch's incredibly successful launch, Call of Duty's record first half performance, and Candy Crush's continued growth as key drivers of our overall performance, we delivered a record Q2," CEO Bobby Kotick said in a statement.Video game sales are often weaker during the middle of the year, as there are fewer releases, while they tend to be stronger around the holidays.Outlook: Full-year EPS of $1.83, below views for $1.88, although Q3 EPS guidance for 39 cents is above views for 36 cents.The company expects full-year revenue of $6.4 billion, compared to analysts' expectations of $6.383 billion. Activision forecast Q3 revenue of $1.49 billion, compared to estimates for $1.508 billion.Activision rose 2% in early after-hours action. Shares closed up 1.1% to 40.83.The stock broke out into buy range in May and touched profit-taking sell territory last month, but it has since pulled back a bit.Estimates: The video game maker is expected to swing to a fiscal Q1 net loss of 29 cents per share, with sales falling 29% to $259.42 million.Results: Net loss of 21 cents a share, revenue rose 13% to $311.6 million.Outlook: The company forecast second-quarter EPS of 35 to 45 cents, above views for 22 cents. Sales are seen at $375 million to $425 million, well above views for $375 million to $425 million, above views for $338.06 million.Take-Two shares rose 3% in early after-hours action. The stock edged down 0.5% to 40.57 at the close but remains above buy territory.Estimates: The travel services website is expected to report EPS of $12.69, up 2%, with revenue rising 13% to $2.58 billion.Results: Priceline earned $13.93, up 12%. Revenue was $2.55 billion, up 12%. Gross bookings rose 19%, above some forecasts.Outlook: Priceline sees Q3 EPS of $28.30-$29.80 with revenue up 12%-17% and bookings up 14%-19%.Priceline soared more than 5% to 1434 in early after-hours trading. Shares had closed down 0.8% to 1359.99, falling back out of buy range after just retaking the entry point of 1,374.08 Wednesday. Priceline shares dipped as TripAdivsor (TRIP) plunged 8.5% on its late Wednesday results.

Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) hit video game "Overwatch" topped the sales charts in June, but overall game software sales dropped 20% year over year, the NPD Group reported late Thursday."Overwatch," a sci-fi shooter game, was the top-selling title in combined U.S. retail and digital download sales last month. It was released worldwide on May 24.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer Software-Gaming sector ranks No. 95 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The top-ranked stocks within the group are NetEase, Electronic Arts and Activision. For more information on these companies, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) "Grand Theft Auto 5," first released in September 2013, came in second place in June, NPD reported.Rounding out the top five, in order, were "Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, "Doom 2016" from Bethesda Softworks, and "Mirror's Edge: Catalyst" from Electronic Arts (EA).Total video game software sales declined to $349.8 million in June from $437.5 million in June 2015, NPD said. Video game hardware sales sank 42% to $181.5 million. Game accessories sales dipped 6% to $120.9 million.Total domestic sales of video game hardware, software and accessories fell 26% to $652.2 million in June, NPD said."Poor comparisons to last June, where software and hardware sales were bolstered by strong launches like 'Batman: Arkham Knight,' led to a sharp 26% year-over-year decline in overall spending across software, hardware and accessories," NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.Activision stock closed up 0.4% at 41.44 in the stock market today, while Take-Two stock rose 1.2% t0 40.56.RELATED:NetEase Hits High Score On 'Overwatch' Game SuccessActivision Game 'Overwatch' Profitability May Be Underappreciated.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Iamgold (IAG) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) were all subject to analyst action Monday. Here's what Wall Street is saying:The bank received a downgrade from Citi to neutral with a 65 price target on valuation.Banks rallied on Friday on hopes for a rate hike from the Federal Reserve, following a solid July jobs report.Shares ended Monday trading down 20 cents to 66.10. on the stock market today.The chipmaker, which supplies Tesla and video game companies, got a price target bump to 69 from 56 from Jefferies, which said Nvidia's products have "momentum" and upside potential in the near term.Nvidia is slated to report earnings late Thursday. Analysts are expecting a whopping 640% in EPS growth from the company.Shares finished trading up 0.9% to 58.74.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia is just one of several highly rated chipmakers to report this week. Inphi and Maxlinear both report after the market close Monday. For more on these chipmakers and other big news this week, check out IBD's weekly Investing Action Plan.The gold stock got upgraded to sector perform from underperform by RBC Capital Markets and received a target hike to 6.50 from 5.50.Amid broader economic volatility, some analysts have been projecting that gold prices will hit $1,500 per ounce next year as the yellow metal enters another bull run.Shares gained 2.5% to 5.68.Stifel raised its price target on Activision (ATVI) by a dollar to 46, while upping its target on Take-Two (TTWO) to 46 from 41.The two video game publishers have been receiving price-target increases left and right, after both companies disclosed quarterly results that pleased Wall Street.Activision ticked up 5 cents to 40.61, while Take-Two lost nearly 1%% to 40.98.

Stocks dipped out of the starting gate on Wednesday, as weak overseas action took an early toll and news from names including Snap (SNAP) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) drove mixed trade at the open.XThe Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq Composite slipped less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 dropped slightly more than 1%, with Davita Healthcare (DVA) and Time Warner (TWX) posting heavy early losses.Wal-MartWMT jumpoed to the head of the Dow, up 0.7% at the starting bell. Walt Disney (DIS) dropped 1%, threatening to snap a three-day rally, and its attempt to climb off the bottom of a five-month consolidation.Apple (AAPL) crept up 0.1%, while FANG stocks were mixed, with Netflix (NFLX) leading the group, up 0.5%.Take-Two Interactive bolted 12% higher after reporting adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings, and third-quarter and full-year guidance above analyst views. The after-hours report also showed net bookings rose during the quarter to $577 million, vs. expectations for $510 million, on the success of its "Grand Theft Auto" and "NBA 2K18" games. The gap up gain marked a rebound from support at the stock's 10-week moving average, but it is not a buy opportunity because shares are extended above a late-stage base.In the beaten-down fiber-optic telecom gear group, Applied OptoElectronics (AAOI) leapt 6% the open. The Sugar Land, Texas-based outfit report a 184% gain in per-share earnings and a 27% rise in sales. Fourth-quarter earnings and revenue guidance was below consensus views, but improved from its prior-quarter expectations. The stock has dived 63% since July.Match.com (MTCH) landed a 16% opening gain. The online dating service reported mixed third-quarter results after Tuesday's close, earnings slipped 14% — more than expected— while revenue growth of 19% topped analyst estimates.  The company's fourth-quarter revenue outlook was well above consensus views, however, due to a growing subscriber base in Match's Tinder Gold mobile app. The gain sent shares beyond a buy range, above a 26.34 buy point from a three-weeks tight pattern.Laser-tools maker Coherent (COHR) flashed 15% higher, rising after reporting late Tuesday its fourth-quarter earnings surged 125% and revenue gained 97%. Both numbers were well above analyst targets.  The gap up move sent the IBD 50 stock past a 272.97 buy point in a first-stage cup-with-handle base.Chicken producer Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) vaulted 5% higher after a solid third-quarter beat. Earnings soared 145% on a 12% rise in revenue, both far above expectations. Shares quickly moved beyond buy range, rebounding from a second test of support at their 10-week moving average, following an August breakout from a double-bottom base.Snapchat parent Snap dropped 9% in early action as a pair of analyst downgrades followed the company's late Tuesday earnings report. The Venice, Calif.-based company's third-quarter earnings fell slightly less than forecast by analysts, but revenue growth of 62% missed estimates and a sharp drop in ad pricing worried investors. Shares rebounded from 20% overnight losses after Snap disclosed China-based internet giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) had established a 12% stake in the company.Overseas, trade was generally weak Wednesday, with Tokyo and Hong Kong both closing lower — Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 0.3%, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 off 0.1% — after posting sharp rallies on Tuesday.  Europe's markets were tightly mixed in afternoon trade, with Frankfurt's DAX down 0.2%, while the CAC-40 in Paris and the FTSE 100 in London climbed into positive territory.Other then the weekly oil inventories, due out report from the Energy Information Administration at 10:30 a.m. ET, Wednesday's economic calendar was quiet. Oil prices traded slightly lower, with the West Texas Intermediate benchmark holding at $47 a barrel, ahead of the report.RELATED:The Big Picture:  Quiet Losses For Nasdaq, S&P 500, But Small Caps ThrashedSquare, Monster, Roku, Alarm.com Lead Investing Action PlanThese 2 Growth Stocks Head Toward Q3 Reports With High Expectations IBD Investor Research Tools Getting Started With IBD

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) late Tuesday reported better-than-expected sales in the September quarter and guided to above-consensus sales for the December quarter. It also raised its sales guidance for the full fiscal year year, ending March 31.XTake-Two stock rocketed 10% higher in after-hours trading on the stock market today. During the regular session, Take-Two fell 0.6% to 106.39.Take-Two expects full-year net bookings of $1.98 billion, based on the midpoint of its guidance, up 4% year over year. Analysts on average were expecting $1.76 billion.Take-Two reported net bookings of $577 million in its fiscal second quarter ended Sept. 30. Analysts were modeling for $510 million. Its results were aided by the continued success of the "Grand Theft Auto" franchise and "NBA 2K18," the latest installment of its pro basketball simulation game.For its fiscal third quarter, Take-Two guided to net bookings of $635 million, topping expectations for $546 million.Take-Two's strong forecast for the holiday sales quarter is in contract to the outlook offered by rivals. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) both missed Wall Street's targets with their December-quarter guidance.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software sports a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. For more analysis on Take-Two and its peers, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two reports quarterly results using generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP, while Wall Street uses non-GAAP figures, making initial comparisons difficult.In the September quarter, Take-Two reported a GAAP loss of 3 cents a share. In the December quarter, it expects to lose 30 cents a share."Our positive momentum continued in the second quarter, enabling Take-Two to deliver another period of better-than-expected operating results," Take-Two Chief Executive Strauss Zelnick said in a news release. "'Grand Theft Auto Online' delivered its best quarter yet, net bookings from 'Grand Theft Auto 5' grew year-over-year, and we enjoyed the successful launch of 'NBA 2K18,' which generated growth in both units sold and recurrent consumer spending."RELATED:Activision Stock Hits Buy Point On Earnings Report, But ReversesElectronic Arts' Holiday-Quarter Sales Outlook Spooks Investors

Futures for the S&P 500 index fell 0.1% vs. fair value early Thursday morning, as Saudi Arabia's foreign minister called for sanctions on Iran for its "support of terrorism," the latest move by the oil kingdom that fuels regional conflict and uncertainty. Japan's Nikkei also reversed from a 25-year high while earnings were mixed. Dow futures lost 0.5%, while Nasdaq 100 futures retreated 0.5% against fair value.XBut the S&P 500 index has climbed 21% and the Nasdaq composite 31% since Donald Trump won the presidential election on Nov. 8, 2016. But the top-performing groups out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks are performing much better.The Building-Residential group is up 104% over the past 52 weeks. D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and NVR (NVR) all among the strong performers. D.R. Horton, a 99 Composite Rating stock, reported quarterly earnings Thursday morning.Computer Software-Gaming has rallied 84% since Trump's election. Penney (JCP) is on tap Friday. In the after-hours session, the stock had been down over 20%. The FANG stock is still in buy range from a 175.59 flat-base entry.Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) soared 11% after beating the Street's fiscal-Q2 targets. Its "Grand Theft Auto" franchise continued to shine with "Grand Theft Auto: Online" delivering its best quarter yet, according to CEO Strauss Zelnick.The video game maker has been a big winner in 2017. From its most recent base — a cup-with-handle pattern with a 80.64 entry — shares are up nearly 50%. The company exceeded Wall Street's earnings and sales estimates in its fiscal Q4.Within the IBD 50, Planet Fitness (PLNT) advanced 15% after the gym owner and operator reported better-than-expected top- and bottom-line results late Tuesday. The stock was breaking out above a 27.32 flat-base entry.On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) dropped over 2%, as the payment processor moved back into buy range from a 98.09 flat-base entry. Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP) crashed on revenue that was far below views, but then pared losses on news that Chinese internet giant Tencent (TCEHY) has taken a big stake. Meanwhile, Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), which has best-possible 99 Composite Rating, soared on strong sales and guidance.XS&P 500 index futures fell 0.1% vs. fair value. Nasdaq 100 and Dow futures lost a fraction.Snap revenue was $207.9 million, up 62% vs. a year earlier but decelerating once again and badly missing the consensus of $236 million. Snap had an adjusted loss of 14 cents, matching views as polled by Zacks Investment Research. Daily active users rose to 178 million, up 17% vs. a year earlier but below estimates for 181.8 million.Snap CEO Evan Spiegel even admitted that Snapchat is sometimes "difficult to understand or hard to use."Shares fell 17% to 12.53 late Tuesday. But shares bounced back before the open in the stock market today on news that Tencent has bought a 12% stake. Snap briefly turned slightly positive, but had faded to trade down about 8% at 13.93.Snap's performance from its IPO to today offers three key lessons for investors.Wait for a proper buy point. Don't try to guess the bottom. And be wary of investing in an upstart rival trying to mess with the established FANG internet giants, in this case Facebook (FB).IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two has a best-possible 99 Composite Rating, which combines several IBD ratings into one overall score. All-time stock winners often have Composite Ratings of 95 or above near the start of their big runs. To learn more about Take-Two, and how it stacks up vs. rivals, check out Stock Checkup.It can be tempting to buy a hot IPO when it debuts, but you should wait for the new stock to prove itself. You should always wait for a proper buy point, such as breaking past a sound entry from a bullish base pattern. But that's especially true for IPOs, which have no frame of reference.Snap, which priced its IPO at 17 a share, rose on its first day of trading, and again on its second. But since then shares trended lower.Snap hit a record low of 11.28 on Aug. 14, soon after its disappointing Q2 results. Shares rallied somewhat, and for the past couple of months have been moving sideways around their 50-day line.But unless you're Warren Buffett, you don't want to try to guess the bottom. You might end up just catching a falling knife. Snap showed some positive action in late March and early May, only to head for new lows.Snap seems headed for a big loss Wednesday, though it currently doesn't seem to be threatening its record low.It is very, very hard for companies to compete with Facebook, Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL). They are huge and have vast resources to fight off upstarts. Most of them generally benefit from network effects. The more people who use their network, the more valuable it becomes.Snap has a strong audience of teens and young adults in North America and Europe. But outside of those regions and age groups, Snap now seems surrounded. Facebook has rapidly copied many of Snap's most popular features, especially via Instagram Stories, which has far more users than Snap. So if you haven't already become a regular Snapchat user, there are strong network effects encouraging you to go with the much-larger Facebook ecosystem.Tencent's entry might change this equation. Upstart Tencent now has a huge backer, one that could potentially help fuel growth in new markets.As for Facebook, the social networking giant recently reported blowout third-quarter earnings and accelerating revenue growth, despite its massive size. More than 2 billion people use Facebook. Its shares are currently in buy range from a proper base.Take-Two Interactive, best known for its "Grand Theft Auto" video game series, reported stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter revenue growth. The video game publisher also guided revenue higher for the holiday Q3, as well as for the full year.Rival video game makers Electronic Arts (EA) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI) both gave weak revenue guidance for the holiday quarter. Shares of both companies retreated since their results.Take-Two shares shot up more than 10% to 117.50 in early trading, suggesting that they'll set a record high Wednesday.The stock has run strongly since gapping out of a base three months ago following its Q1 results. The stock hasn't provided a new entry point, just pulling back modestly in recent days from a record high.RELATED:The Big Picture: These 5 Stocks Made Big MovesTencent Buys 12% Of Snap; Snapchat Parent's Stock Off LowsSnap Revenue, User Growth Short Of Views; Stock DivesTake-Two Interactive Software Beats Sales Target, Guides HigherSquare, Monster Beverage, Roku, Alarm.com Lead Investing Action Plan

The major market averages were sharply mixed in morning trade Monday amid renewed momentum from tax reform. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 1.2%, while the S&P 500 moved up 0.7%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq turned red, falling 0.1%.X Among the Dow Jones Industrial components, global investment banks JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) advanced over 2% and 0.7%, respectively. Shares of JPMorgan are about 12% above a 95.32 flat-base entry, while Goldman was about 1% above a 247.18 saucer-with-handle buy point. Both stocks found support at their 50-day lines last week.Among other top financial stocks, Morgan Stanley (MS) rose 2%, while Bank of America (BAC) jumped over 3%. Both stocks are extended from their recent buy points after successful tests of the 50-day line.FANG stocks gave back all of their gains in early trading Monday in the stock market today, as tech stocks tried to recover from last week's sell-off. Netflix (NFLX) reversed lower to decline 2% despite analyst firm Monness Crespi Hardt initiating coverage on the video streaming firm with a buy rating and a 250 price target — an almost-34% premium to Friday's closing price. Shares are below their 190.05 cup-with-handle entry and 50-day line.Aetna (AET) rose almost 2% after it was announced that CVS Health (CVS) will pay $207 per share for the health insurer. Shares of Aetna were above 12% above a 164.62 flat-base entry. Meanwhile, shares of the pharmacy store dropped 3% to fall back below its 50-day line. The e-commerce giant was on pace to extend a losing streak to six days that has seen the stock fall over 12%. Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) jumped to a record high on Monday after getting a bullish report from a Wall Street firm, while China-based rival NetEase (NTES) sank on a stock downgrade.XMKM Partners on Monday reiterated its buy rating on Take-Two and raised its price target to 122 from 97. Take-Two hit an all-time high of 110 in intraday trading on the stock market today, and ended the regular session up 1.7% to 109.71.MKM analyst Eric Handler is upbeat on Take-Two for its current and upcoming game slate. The company's "Grand Theft Auto Online" game continues to perform well and its recently launched "NBA 2K18" basketball game looks strong. He anticipates better-than-consensus results from Take-Two when it reports fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market close Nov. 7."The ongoing strength of the GTA franchise and 'NBA 2K' are likely the key drivers for outperformance," Handler said in a report. "More importantly, last month's new 'Red Dead Redemption 2' trailer was very well received and has produced very positive buzz. We continue to wait on news about an actual release date as well as a possible 'Borderlands 3' announcement."Among Take-Two's rivals, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) climbed 1.8% to 65.30, while Electronic Arts (EA) added 0.7% to 117.58.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software has an IBD Composite Rating of 98, meaning it has outperformed 98% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more analysis on Take-Two and its peers, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, investment bank UBS downgraded NetEase to neutral from buy and lowered its 12-month price target to 300 from 326.NetEase shares finished regular trading Monday down 2.5% to 276.51.NetEase mobile games such as "Onmyoji" are showing weakness and the company has no new hit games, UBS analyst Angela Xu said in a report."We like NetEase's strong R&D team, mobile MMORPG (Massively Multiplayer Online Role-Playing Game) strength, and potential from strategic layouts and future new titles. But we think near-term visibility on the next hit title is relatively low," she said.RELATED:Nintendo Nearly Doubles Profit Outlook As Switch Hits Home RunCrime Pays For Take-Two: 'Grand Theft Auto' Keeps Printing Money

Electronic Arts (EA) shares fell Wednesday as investors reacted to news that the video-game publisher is shutting down a studio that was making a future Star Wars game.Redwood City, Calif.-based EA announced late Tuesday that it is closing its Visceral studio, delaying an action-adventure game set in the Star Wars universe. The game was supposed to launch during the company's fiscal year 2019, which runs from April 2018 through March 2019. EA is moving development of the title to another team with leadership based in Vancouver."It has become clear that to deliver an experience that players will want to come back to and enjoy for a long time to come, we needed to pivot the design," Patrick Soderlund, executive vice president of EA Worldwide Studios, said in a post on the company's website. "While we had originally expected this game to launch late in our fiscal year 2019, we're now looking at a new time frame that we will announce in the future."EA was down 2.4% to finish the regular trading session at 113.16 on the stock market today.Investment bank Morgan Stanley cut its price target on EA stock to 126 from 128 on the news, but kept its overweight rating."Disappointing titles from earlier this year and the delay (in the Star Wars game) will likely fuel bearish sentiment; however, we remain positive on (the) shift to digital (distribution) and strong results from core franchises," Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak said in a report.Nowak lowered his fiscal 2019 estimates for EA's earnings per share by 8% after removing the Star Wars game from his model."We acknowledge this delay, combined with the disappointing 'Mass Effect' title from earlier this year, is likely to fuel some investors' cries around the company's lackluster track record in developing new (intellectual property) and titles … and the multiple investors will pay for this asset," Nowak said. "These are challenges for EA to work through, but in our view EA is still likely to benefit and drive the digital gaming transition, and we remain positive on the strong results set to come from 'FIFA,' 'Battlefield' and 'Star Wars: Battlefront.' "IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts is currently ranked No. 34 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks.EA is scheduled to release "Star Wars: Battlefront 2" on Nov. 17.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz says the delay in the Visceral Star Wars game is likely to be lengthy."We doubt this will be a short-term delay as the game appears likely to undergo a substantial rework, from a linear story-based game to a broader (read: live services-enabled) player experience," Creutz said. "Fiscal 2021 is likely the earliest we will see the title."Meanwhile, rival game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) received a price-target increase on Wednesday from BMO Capital Markets.BMO analyst Gerrick Johnson upped his target to 125 from 100 and kept his outperform rating.Take-Two stock was up 0.7% to end the day at 104.61."Sales of 'Grand Theft Auto 5' and monetization in the GTA Online game mode have been occurring at a faster rate than we previously expected," Johnson said in a report. "And with a muted impact on (Take-Two's) 'NBA 2K18' from Electronic Arts' relaunch of 'NBA Live,' we are confident Take-Two will continue to post earnings results ahead of its guidance as well as Street consensus estimates."RELATED:Glu Mobile Turnaround Taking Shape Thanks To Taylor SwiftTeen Survey Reveals Hottest Video Games This Holiday Season

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) is likely to benefit from its lucrative, long-running crime saga "Grand Theft Auto" when it reports September-quarter results in two weeks.Take-Two's release of new content for "Grand Theft Auto Online" last quarter could help the company beat consensus sales and earnings numbers in its fiscal second quarter, KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Evan Wingren said Wednesday. That content, "Smuggler's Run," debuted on Aug. 29." 'Smuggler's Run' followed up the highly successful 'Gunrunning' GTA Online expansion," Wingren said in a note to clients. "Search volume for 'Smuggler's Run' was about 75% as high relative to 'Gunrunning,' implying that interest (and likely engagement) in GTA Online remained near record levels in the second quarter.""Grand Theft Auto Online" sales remain robust, but are likely to decelerate, he said. Wingren reiterated his overweight rating on Take-Two and raised his price target on the stock to 119 from 104.Take-Two shares lost 0.3% to close at 104.87 on the stock market today. Take-Two hit a record high of 107.53 on Oct. 6.In addition to its Grand Theft Auto franchise, Take-Two is riding strong demand trends for its "NBA 2K18" basketball game and high interest in its upcoming Wild West action game "Red Dead Redemption 2," Wingren said.Elsewhere on Wall Street, Credit Suisse raised its price targets on three video game publishers: Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two is currently ranked No. 2 in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which stock leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju rates Activision and EA as outperform and Take-Two as neutral.He raised his price targets as follows: Activision to 77 from 74, EA to 130 from 117 and Take-Two to 95 from 73.Activision was down 1.5% to close at 61.81, while EA was up 1% to 114.56.RELATED:Activision Poised To Win Holiday Video Game SeasonElectronic Arts Loses The Force After Delaying 'Star Wars' Game

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is likely to be the big winner in video game sales this holiday shopping season, an analyst predicted Tuesday.XJefferies analyst Timothy O'Shea reiterated his buy rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 80 from 78 on an improved outlook.Activision "should win the holiday," with key games "Destiny 2" and "Call of Duty: WWII" both "looking solid," O'Shea said in a report. "Destiny 2" was released on Sept. 3 and "Call of Duty: WWII" is due out on Nov. 3.O'Shea also raised his price target on Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) to 123 from 108 and maintained his buy rating.Activision shares climbed 2.1% to close at 62.73 on the stock market today. Take-Two stock ticked up 0.2% to finish at 105.22.He increased his sales and earnings estimates for Take-Two for next year based on increasing optimism around its "Red Dead Redemption 2" game, set for release next spring.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has formed a flat base with a buy point of 66.68 over the past eight weeks. For more analysis on Activision, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.The "biggest question mark" this holiday season is how the Electronic Arts (EA) game "Star Wars Battlefront 2" will perform, O'Shea said. He noted that there's a backlash brewing among gamers over how much EA is pushing microtransactions in the game to drive sales."Some beta testers are criticizing the game for having an overly aggressive monetization scheme," O'Shea said. "We still think the game could drive material upside to EPS estimates if this game can generate deep user engagement. But 'Star Wars Battlefront 2' now looks like the biggest question mark of all the major holiday titles and we will be tracking sales and engagement trends closely to see whether this backlash materializes into underperformance."O'Shea rates EA stock as buy with a price target of 135. EA ended the regular trading session down 0.2% to finish at 113.39.RELATED:Electronic Arts Loses The Force After Delaying Star Wars GameTeen Survey Reveals Hottest Video Games This Holiday Season

A survey of U.S. teens released Wednesday reveals the most sought-after video game this holiday season is historical combat title "Call of Duty: WWII" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI).Investment bank Piper Jaffray said 29% of the over 3,600 video-game-playing teens it surveyed selected "Call of Duty: WWII" as the game they're most excited about buying this year. Tied for second place with 10% each were sci-fi shooter game "Destiny 2" from Activision and western action game "Red Dead Redemption 2" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).Overall, the video game industry in the U.S. appears healthy, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a note to clients. Interest in owning a current-generation console remains strong, with 79% of respondents having either already upgraded to one or planning to do so within the next two years. That's up from 75% in Piper Jaffray's spring teen survey."The rising level of interest and ownership in consoles is a clear positive for the game publishers (Activision, EA, Take-Two) as it speaks to the console cycle's potential to drive (software) growth in the remainder of 2017 and 2018," Olson said.The fourth most anticipated game is "Star Wars Battlefront 2" from Electronic Arts (EA) at 7% of votes, followed by "Super Mario Odyssey" from Nintendo (NTDOY) with 6%."Destiny 2" was released on Sept. 6. "Super Mario Odyssey" is due out Oct. 27, followed by "Call of Duty: WWII" on Nov. 3 and "Star Wars Battlefront 2" on Nov. 17. The release of "Red Dead Redemption 2" was delayed from holiday season until the second quarter of 2018.He rates shares of those three publishers as overweight. His price target for Activision is 69, with EA at 128 and Take-Two at 100.Activision was down 0.2% to close at 61.36 on the stock market today. EA was down 1.5% to end the regular trading day at 116.05, and Take-Two was up 0.9% to finish at 103.60.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts is currently ranked No. 30 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks.Activision, EA and Take-Two are benefiting from the shift to higher-margin digital downloads and away from packaged media.About 50% of teen gamers surveyed said they expect at least half their video game purchases to be full-game downloads this year, up from 45% in the spring and 40% a year ago.Teen gamers also like to watch online videos of other people playing games, such as instructional videos, "play-throughs" and esports, Olson said.Some 61% of teen gamers watch others play games online, mostly on Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned YouTube and Amazon (AMZN)-owned Twitch. And 25% said they watch esports, professional video game matches."This bodes well for esports, as more organized and widely broadcast events are scheduled to launch over the next year," Olson said.RELATED:Video Game Stocks 'Heading Into Choppy Waters,' Analyst SaysCan Esports' Armchair Gladiators Vanquish Hulking NFL Players?

The S&P 500 index and other major averages edged lower through Thursday as tax reform concerns weighted on the market. Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP) crashed on weak revenue and user growth. As for M&A, Broadcom (AVGO) made a $130 billion bid for fellow Apple (AAPL) supplier Qualcomm (QCOM), while reports surfaced that Walt Disney had held talks to buy much of 21st Century Fox (FOXA).The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow industrials gave up weekly gains on fears that tax cuts would be delayed, closing slightly lower but still near record highs. Earnings remained heavy, with Nvidia (NVDA) leading chip earnings. Roku (ROKU) streamed higher on its strong, first-ever earnings report while fellow recent IPOs Snap and The Trade Desk (TTD) crashed. Bank stocks were notable losers for the week. Crude oil futures hit a 2-year high amid Saudi turmoil, but U.S. production hit record highs.Broadcom (AVGO) launched an unsolicited bid to buy wireless-chip maker Qualcomm (QCOM) in a deal worth $130 billion, which would make it the largest technology acquisition ever. Qualcomm is likely to reject the $70-a-share offer on the basis that it's too low. A deal also would have big antitrust hurdles. Qualcomm rose 4.5% to 64.57 after spiking nearly 13% on Nov. 3 as deal reports first hit. Broadcom retreated 3.2% but stayed in a buy range.Chipmakers Nvidia (NVDA), Microchip Technology (MCHP) and ON Semiconductor (ON) posted beat-and-raise quarterly reports. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) beat Wall Street's targets for the September quarter, but gave in-line guidance. Among chip-gear makers, Brooks Automation (BRKS) beat fiscal fourth-quarter forecast and guided current-quarter forecasts higher, but shares still tumbled Thursday and Friday following the results.Roku (ROKU) rocketed 55% Thursday after the streaming video firm reported much better-than-expected results for the third quarter, its first as a publicly traded company. Roku then rose to a record high Friday. Roku ended the third quarter with 16.7 million active users on its content distribution platform, up 48% year over year. Average revenue per user grew 37% year over year to $12.68. Roku makes hardware and software for accessing internet video services like Netflix (NFLX), Hulu and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video.Analysts tore into Snapchat-owner Snap (SNAP) after a third-quarter earnings report that missed estimates on many metrics, including revenue and user growth. Snap CEO Evan Spiegel acknowledged complaints that Snapchat is "hard to use" and said that the app will be redesigned. Shares crashed 16%, even with Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) buying a 12% stake in the social media firm.RELATED:Snap Slammed On Quarterly Results As Tencent Acquires A StakeThree China internet companies, Sina (SINA), Weibo (WB) and Autohome (ATHM), all reported quarterly results that beat expectations. Sina owns a controlling stake in Weibo. Chinese video game publisher NetEase (NTES) said it will push deeper into e-commerce, with plans to spend $11 billion on products from the U.S., Europe and Japan to sell to local consumers.Search-engine company Sogou (SOGO) raised $585 million in an initial public offering, selling 45 million shares at 13, the high end of its estimated range. Shares rose to 13.51 in Thursday's debut and closed Friday at 13.86. China-based Sohu (SOHU), an internet service company that includes gaming, holds the largest stake in Sogou, which is also backed by Tencent (TCEHY). Tencent leads China's messaging services field and aims to deepen its relationship with Sogou, posing a threat to China search-engine leader Baidu (BIDU).Nordstrom (JWN) roundly topped profit and revenue forecasts. But same-store sales disappointed and the upscale department store trimmed the high end of profit outlook. Meanwhile, Macy's (M) missed revenue estimates and comps sank 4%, but beaten-down shares soared on better-than-expected earnings. Kohl's (KSS) EPS missed views but the retailer lifted the bottom end of EPS targets. J.C. Penney (JCP) reported better-than-expected Q3 results after recently slashing full-year guidance.Walt Disney (DIS) disclosed a surprise drop in Q4 profit and revenue amid reports of more upcoming ESPN layoffs, but CEO Bob Iger announced that there would be a brand-new "Star Wars" trilogy, gave its ESPN streaming platform a name and launch date, and said its Disney-only over-the-top service would be priced "substantially below" Netflix (NFLX), reversing shares higher late Thursday. Meanwhile, reports surfaced that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) had held talks to sell the bulk of itself to Disney. Iger refused to address "press speculation" on the call. Disney rose solidly more than 6%. 21st Century Fox, which reported solid results, shot up 15.5%.On Monday, oil prices rose to their highest levels since mid-2015 on political unrest in the Middle East. Crude closed the week with a 2.3% gain to $56.74 a barrel. Saudi Arabia arrested several members of the royal family over the prior week and said that a missile attack from Yemen and supported by Iran could be considered an "act of war." U.S. crude production rose to 9.62 million barrels per day, the highest since Energy Information Administration began tracking weekly data in 1983. Domestic crude supplies unexpectedly rose. Continental Resources (CLR), Diamondback Energy (FANG), Matador Resources (MTDR), and Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) topped quarterly forecasts, while Parsley Energy (PE) turned in mixed results as shale producers continued to stress capital spending discipline in their Q3 reports.RELATED:U.S. Crude Production Hits Record High, Stockpiles Unexpectedly RiseVideo game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) reported better-than-expected September-quarter results and guided higher for the holiday sales quarter after Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) recently gave disappointing guidance. Take-Two is benefiting from continued demand for its "Grand Theft Auto" franchise and strong sales of basketball game "NBA 2K18." Meanwhile, Activision said "Call of Duty: WWII" surpassed $500 million in global sales in its first three days of availability.Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) rose to a record high on upbeat data for a postpartum depression drug while Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) popped on news a British billionaire could buy a stake. Investment bank Cowen soured on video game stocks on Monday, downgrading shares of Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and European-traded Ubisoft.X"After a tremendous five-year run, we think the video game stocks are heading into choppy waters," Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a report. "Implied buy-side expectations for next year suggest a level of aggregate growth that we think is highly unrealistic."Creutz lowered his ratings on Activision, Take-Two and Ubisoft to market perform from outperform. He maintained his price targets on Activision and Take-Two at 66 and 83, respectively. He previously cut his rating on Electronic Arts (EA) to market perform with a price target of 106.Activision fell 3.3% to close at 61.18 on the stock market today. Take-Two was down 2.9% to end the regular trading day at 104.11, while EA dropped 1.2% to finish at 118.62.Creutz said he believes Activision and Take-Two are fairly valued now, but will face intense competition in 2018.Next year's game slate for the industry "looks loaded," Creutz said. Led by Take-Two's "Red Dead Redemption 2," possibly Activision's "Call of Duty: Black Ops 4" and new "Battlefield" game from Electronic Arts, "next year's slate appears to be the most top-heavy of at least the last five years."IBD'S TAKE: One video game stock has formed a "super bullish" chart pattern. See the article "These 5 Top Stocks Have Etched This 'Super' Bullish Pattern.""As games engage their audiences for longer periods of time (and generate more revenue thereby), consumers are becoming more selective about which games they play," Creutz said. "We expect the number of successful titles to continue to narrow over the next several years."Also, Activision has the potential for "sentiment disappointments" around growth initiatives such as esports and in-game advertising for mobile games, he said.Meanwhile, Take-Two is likely to reach an earnings peak next fiscal year, he said.RELATED:Can Esports' Armchair Gladiators Vanquish Hulking NFL Players?

As several thousand people file into the KeyArena in Seattle to cheer on their favorite players, the excitement builds. Contestants warm up, fans get charged, and broadcasters speculate breathlessly on what's about to take place.Once the action gets underway, the on-air commentators don't hold back their enthusiasm. At one point, the arena erupts in thunderous cheers when a rather conspicuous player occupying a patch of grass on the field of battle is suddenly blown to bits."Get off my lawn," gushes the wry play-by-play man.A dystopian nightmare? Far from it. It's the International Dota 2 Championship for video-game players, known as "the Super Bowl of esports," all captured for posterity on YouTube. And that ill-fated contestant was an animated character in the game.Some might scoff, but it's no joke — esports are growing up fast. They've been touted as the next big thing in professional sports, attracting millions of young fans and threatening the likes of sporting titans like the National Football League and National Basketball Association — both of which are suffering from declining viewership. At stake for video-game publishers is a potentially lucrative new business that could generate billions in advertising, sponsorships, ticket sales, broadcast rights and related business.Backers of esports believe that the world of professional competitive video games will eventually yield Michael Jordan-level stars that fans will idolize and try to emulate. More than 40 players have racked up earnings in excess of $1 million each from esports tournaments so far. There's even talk about adding esports competitions to the 2024 Olympics in Paris.To be sure, though, video games are not your typical spectator sport.At the recent "Dota 2" gathering in Seattle, held in August, the teams of actual live humans operated in relative anonymity behind glass fortresses — an occasional camera shot might have focused on a tense-looking player.Most of the attention, though, went to the spectacular hologram characters selected in an ersatz draft for the coming battle, played out on large video screens over the center stage. Spectators watched the action on a large stage for a prize pool worth $24.8 million. The winners, Europe-based Team Liquid, took home the top prize of $10.8 million, besting a team called Newbee.The hype around esports reached new heights in July as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) started selling teams in its new Overwatch League for a reported $20 million each.The idea of competitive video games as a sport is bound to strike many adults of a certain age as odd. Players sit at PCs or game consoles and control the on-screen action with hand controllers or keyboards and mice. Quick thinking and fast hand-eye coordination are traits of the best esports "athletes.""People have yet to legitimize gaming as a credible pastime," Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said. "It's like the argument over whether golf is a real sport."But indications are that many young people would rather watch online gaming competitions than traditional sports like football, basketball and soccer. Esports games range from military-strategy shooter games and fantasy role-playing combat games to simulations of real-world sports."Kids like to watch esports, whether they're players or not," Hickey said. And the youthful demographic is highly sought after by advertisers, who have trouble reaching that age group through traditional ads.Esports is "a big deal," Hickey said.Research firm Newzoo predicts that the global audience for esports will reach 385 million this year, made up of 191 million esports enthusiasts plus 194 million occasional viewers. Most of their viewing takes place online. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to account for 51% of the esports enthusiasts this year, with North America making up 13%.Newzoo is forecasting the esports audience to reach 589 million worldwide in 2020, with 51% of those being core esports enthusiasts.Newzoo estimates that the esports market will generate $696 million in sales this year, up 41% from 2016. Of that, sponsorships will account for 38% of revenue, followed by advertising with 22%, game publisher fees at 17%, media rights taking in 14% and merchandise and tickets ringing up 9%.Esports revenue is seen rising to $1.49 billion in 2020, according to Newzoo. But that big number is fragmented by different games and tournament organizers.Companies best positioned to capitalize on the growing esports trend are those that own the games being played, analysts say.The leading publishers in esports now are Activision, Tencent (TCEHY)-owned Riot Games with "League of Legends," and privately held Valve with "Counter-Strike: Global Offensive" and "Dota 2."Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision owns the "Overwatch," "Starcraft," "Hearthstone" and "Call of Duty" franchises, which are already popular in competitive gaming.While Valve allows other companies to run competitions featuring its games, Activision, Tencent's Riot and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) are seeking to manage all aspects of esports with their games.On July 12, Activision announced the sale of the first seven team franchises in its upcoming Overwatch League, which is billed as the first major global professional esports league with city-based teams. Those new teams will be based in Boston, New York, Miami-Orlando, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Shanghai and Seoul.On Sept. 20, it completed the first season lineup of 12 city-based teams. It added teams in London, Philadelphia, Dallas and Houston, plus a second team in Los Angeles. The inaugural season for the new arena-based league begins Jan. 10, with preseason matches starting Dec. 6.Meanwhile, Riot Games announced in June that it will franchise the North American League of Legends Championship Series starting in 2018, with teams becoming permanent partners.And Take-Two has launched the NBA 2K esports league with the National Basketball Association. In May, the league announced that 17 NBA teams will participate in the inaugural season, set to debut in 2018.While some video-game publishers like Activision view esports as a significant new revenue stream, others like Electronic Arts (EA) view it as mostly a promotional tool to sell more games and downloadable content."Esports is going to be an important part of most large-scale video games going forward," Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said. "It's a great way to create more usage and engagement with games."Plus, esports tournaments offer "real revenue-generating opportunities on their own," he said.In the past, video games mirrored the movie business, with titles generating the bulk of their revenue in a short period of time. Now games can generate significant revenue for years through downloadable content, online services and esports, DFC Intelligence analyst David Cole said.Esports communities can keep a game relevant for a long period of time, Cole said.Most esports tournament viewing is online today through services like Amazon.com (AMZN)-owned Twitch and Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned YouTube. Traditional broadcasters have joined the fray as well, including Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN and Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting. Esports promoters hope to grow the audience for watching competitive gaming in person at arena events, some of which already draw thousands of fans for tournaments.One open question is whether esports fans will take to following the city-based teams proposed by Activision for "Overwatch" and Take-Two for "NBA 2K."Much of esports viewing centers on major championships for games, not run-of-the-mill matches.Also, esports activity around the top games developed organically over many years, while Activision and Take-Two are trying to drive the esports aspect of their games."League of Legends" generates the most online viewership in video games today, getting about 40% to 50% of viewers for competitions and instructional videos, Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said. "Dota 2" and "CS:GO" are the next two biggest. "Overwatch," released in May 2016, is fourth, with perhaps 10% of online viewership, Pachter said.The top three games are compelling to watch, while science-fiction shooter game "Overwatch" for now isn't, he said. The same goes for Take-Two's pro basketball video game, Pachter said."EA and Take-Two talk about their sports simulation games," Pachter said. "But the problem is we can already watch real athletes play real sports, so why would we want to watch video gamers play simulated sports?"Analysts will be closely watching the rollout of the Overwatch and NBA 2K leagues to see if they live up to the hype."The indications seem to be very positive at this point," Sebastian said.RELATED:Activision Blizzard Earns Kudos For 'Overwatch' E-Sports MovesThese 3 Stocks Are Plays On The Fast-Growing E-Sports Market

Key U.S. stock indexes sold off Wednesday as earnings reports continued and amid renewed talk about changes to 401(k) contribution limits.Nike (NKE) led the Dow Jones industrial average with a 4% jump, but Boeing (BA), General Electric (GE) and Caterpillar (CAT) weighed with losses of more than 2% each. Boeing's Q3 earnings beat views, but its implied Q4 guidance disappointed.XSPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) and PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) sank 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively, while SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) dropped 0.8% in the stock market today. Emerging markets reversed lower as iShares MSCI Emerging Markets (EEM) fell 0.5%.The sell-off hit sector funds across the board. Homebuilders, semiconductor and retail were among the biggest losers: SPDR S&P Homebuilders (XHB) slumped 1.8%, VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) lost 1.4% and SPDR S&P Retail (XRT) gave up 1.2%. Sectors with the smallest losses included health care, real estate and gold miners, with declines ranging from 0.2% to 0.6%.Oil funds also slid along with a 0.8% drop in West Texas intermediate crude prices to $52.05 a barrel. United States Oil (USO) and PowerShares DB Oil (DBO) each fell about 0.8%. SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production (XOP) skidded 1.6%; VanEck Vectors Oil Services (OIH) gave up 0.7%.Small caps have slowed down from their recent torrid pace, leaving two small-cap exchange traded funds in buy range.Vanguard Small-Cap (VB) broke out past a 139.47 flat-base buy point Sept. 27 and is holding about 2% above the entry. That base started forming its shape after a 2% advance from a prior flat base cleared in July.The 13-year-old fund, which tracks the CRSP U.S. Small Cap Index, has amassed $19.9 billion in assets. The diversified index is made up of U.S. stocks whose market caps are smaller than the biggest 85% and bigger than the smallest 2%. The median market cap of the stocks is $3.9 billion.VB held more than 1,400 stocks in its portfolio as of Sept. 30. The biggest sector weightings were as follows: 25.5% in financials, 20.5% in industrials, about 11% each in consumer services and technology, and nearly 11% in health care. Top names included medical devices maker Teleflex (TFX), video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and tech services provider CDW (CDW).The market-weighted fund is broadly diversified — its top 10 holdings account for 3% of total assets. Its 21.4% year-to-date return is ahead of the S&P 500's 16.4% gain. Its average annual returns over the past three and five years slightly lag the benchmark index, but it leads over the past 10 years. The ETF carries a 0.06% expense ratio.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software has delivered a solid performance this year, but how do its fundamentals and technicals rank in its industry group? Find out now at IBD Stock Checkup.Schwab U.S. Small Cap (SCHA) also remains in buy range after clearing a flat base late last month. The ideal buy point was 65.90, or a dime above the left-side high of the pattern. SCHA also climbed 2% from a previous flat-base breakout.The $6.2 billion fund, which will mark its eighth anniversary next month, tracks the Dow Jones U.S. Small-Cap Total Stock Market Index. The index comprises about 1,750 small-cap stocks. The average market cap of SCHA's holdings is $2.4 billion, according to Morningstar Direct.Financials made up 19% of assets as of Oct. 23, with information technology at 17%, industrials at 15%, and health care and consumer discretionary at about 13% apiece. Truck maker Oshkosh (OSK), RV maker Thor Industries (THO) and biotech Bluebird Bio (BLUE) were among its top holdings. The top 10 names represented 2% of the portfolio.SCHA returned 11.2% YTD, with three-year and five-year average annual returns of 10.9% and 14.7%, respectively. Its expense ratio is 0.05%.Tuesday's picks, First Trust Dow Jones Internet (FDN) and First Trust Cloud Computing (SKYY), remain in a buy zone from their respective entries at 101.94 and 41.78.RELATED:Earnings Fuel Dow To New Record High; 2 FANG Plays In Buy ZoneDow Holds Gain As Wal-Mart Rises; Nvidia Leads Hot Chip SectorApple, Boeing Lift Dow To New High; This Stock Play In Buy Zone
