Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) stock jumped to a record high on Friday after the "Grand Theft Auto" video game maker reported better-than-expected September quarter results.Late Thursday, Take-Two said that it had earned 30 cents a share excluding items on sales of $365 million in its fiscal second quarter, which ended Sept. 30. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Take-Two to earn 15 cents a share minus items on sales of $318 million.On a year-over-year basis, sales were up 169%, marking the company's fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth.The New York-based company also increased its financial outlook for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2016.Big contributors to Take-Two's revenue growth in fiscal Q2 included popular games such "NBA 2K16," "Grand Theft Auto 5," "Grand Theft Auto Online" and "Borderlands: The Handsome Collection."Revenue from digitally delivered content rose 57% year over year to $141 million in the quarter. Digital sales accounted for 39% of Take-Two's total revenue in fiscal Q2."Our holiday season is off to a great start, including the successful release of 'WWE 2K16,' and we expect the installed base of new-gen consoles to expand further and broaden our global audience," Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said in a statement.Take-Two stock rose 3.5% to 34.20 on the stock market today. Earlier in the session, it hit an all-time high of 37.Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald maintained his buy rating on Take-Two and boosted his price target to 44 from 37.Take-Two is benefiting from "two powerful tailwinds," Fitzgerald said in a research note Thursday. Those factors include faster-than-expected sales of new-generation game consoles like Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4.The other factor is "the transition to digital revenue streams, which means the company is structurally more profitable than ever," he said.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Take-Two stock and raised his price target to 39 from 37.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz maintained his outperform rating on the stock and price target of 36."Like other major publishers, Take-Two continues to benefit from better monetization and margins on franchises through the digital window and has raised its full-year outlook, despite delaying one game into next year," he said in a research note Friday. Take-Two bumped its release of new franchise "Battleborn" to May 2, 2016, to allow for extended development of the game. It was originally set to launch in February."With 'Battleborn' and 'Mafia 3' lined up for fiscal 2017, and other potential franchise titles in the offing such as 'Red Dead' or 'Borderlands,' we believe next year should be a robust growth year for the company," Creutz said.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian reiterated his neutral rating on Take-Two but upped his price target to 38 from 33.Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter @IBD_PSeitz and on Facebook.

The IBD 50 stock is a leading provider of online gaming, including "World of Warcraft,"…

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) late Thursday surprised Wall Street with better-than-expected September-quarter sales and earnings, thanks to its popular sports games. It also raised guidance for the year based on anticipation for its blockbuster "Star Wars: Battlefront" game.

For its fiscal Q2 ended Sept. 30, EA earned 65 cents a share excluding items, down 11% year over year but better than the 45 cents expected by Wall Street. Sales dipped 6% to $1.15 billion, which topped the Street's forecast for $1.10 billion. Sales would have been up 3% year over year if not for foreign-exchange-rate effects.
For the December quarter, EA expects to earn $1.75 a share ex items, up 43%, on sales of $1.78 billion, up 24%.

"Our markets are very healthy, the digital transition continues to drive margins, and engagement in our live services and excitement for our upcoming launches is exceptional," EA Chief Financial Officer Blake Jorgensen said in a statement.

Despite the beat, Electronic Arts shares were down 4%, near 73, in morning trading in the stock market today, the day after shares touched an all-time high of 76.92. EA stock maintains a strong IBD Relative Strength Rating of 96, where 99 is the highest.
Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz reiterated his buy rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 95 from 80.

"If EA can post such solid results in its 'tough quarter,' we are even more optimistic around the holiday, when key title 'Star Wars: Battlefront' drops on Nov. 17," Pitz said in a research report. "EA continues to benefit from two powerful tailwinds: 1) fast console sales and 2) the digital transition, which is resulting in EA being structurally more profitable than ever."
EA's fiscal Q2 was driven by strong sales of "Madden NFL 16" and "FIFA 16."
Based on a successful beta test, EA upped its sales estimate for "Star Wars: Battlefront" to 13 million units from a range of 9 million to 10 million.

Digital game sales, including full game downloads and add-on content, accounted for 42% of revenue in fiscal Q2. Digital sales are more profitable than packaged game sales. EA is projecting 56% of sales to be digital this fiscal year.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz maintained his outperform rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 79 from 74.
"EA put up yet another strong quarter, with top and bottom line upside driven by continued impressive monetization of the company's sports franchises," Creutz said in a note.
EA and other game publishers, such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), have benefited from the console upgrade cycle hitting the sweet spot.
The installed base of Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 consoles has reached a sufficient level to drive big software sales.

Retail video game sales toss air ball in September

Activision Blizzard's  (ATVI) BlizzCon drew in 25,000 attendees to Anaheim, many of them there to watch the StarCraft II global finals between South Korean pro-gamers SOS and Life. BlizzCon is an event held by Blizzard Entertainment, a division of Activision Blizzard. Competitive gaming gets its fair share of criticism, but the industry is expected to reach almost $2 billion…
Sports video games topped another down month for traditional video game sales at U.S. retail stores in September, NPD Group reported late Monday.

Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail stores fell 9% year over year to $1.01 billion. Game hardware sales dropped 27% to $313.5 million. Game software sales dipped 3% to $465.6 million. Game accessories were a bright spot, rising 20% to $230.5 million, NPD said.

Three of the top five best-selling packaged video games were sports titles. Basketball game "NBA 2K16" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) came in first, followed by football game "Madden NFL 16" from Electronic Arts (EA). "Madden NFL 16" was the top-selling game in August.
"Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain" from Konami Digital Entertainment grabbed third place, followed by soccer game "FIFA 16" from EA and "Destiny: The Taken King" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI).

Leading up to the fourth quarter, year-to-date spending across game hardware, software and accessories was down 1%. But with a strong lineup of software titles, a price cut to Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 console and compelling hardware bundles, NPD is expecting a positive 2015 holiday season, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in statement.
The current generation of video game consoles, led by the PS4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, are outselling the prior generation of game machines, he said.
"After 23 months on the market, combined PS4 and Xbox One sales are 40% higher than the combined 23 month totals for PS3 and Xbox 360," Callahan said.

Gauging the health of the video game industry from retail sales of new packaged software is difficult because the NPD statistics do not account for the growing percentage of game sales coming from digital downloads.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz sees a turnaround for physical game software sales in October and the holiday shopping season.

"We currently expect a major double-digit increase in physical sales in October, driven by the launches of 'Halo 5' and 'Assassin's Creed: Syndicate' vs. a year-ago comp that included no major non-sports AAA launches," Creutz said in a research report Tuesday. "Currently we expect sales in the holiday window to be roughly flat, with the year finishing in slightly positive territory."

Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report that the installed base of current-generation game systems is now big enough, at about 40 million units, "to drive sustainable software growth on a quarterly basis."Sports video games topped another down month for traditional video game sales at U.S. retail stores in September, NPD Group reported late Monday.Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail stores fell 9% year over year to $1.01 billion. Game hardware sales dropped 27% to $313.5 million. Game software sales dipped 3% to $465.6 million. Game accessories were a bright spot, rising 20% to $230.5 million, NPD said.Three of the top five best-selling packaged video games were sports titles. Basketball game "NBA 2K16" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) came in first, followed by football game "Madden NFL 16" from Electronic Arts (EA). "Madden NFL 16" was the top-selling game in August."Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain" from Konami Digital Entertainment grabbed third place, followed by soccer game "FIFA 16" from EA and "Destiny: The Taken King" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI).Leading up to the fourth quarter, year-to-date spending across game hardware, software and accessories was down 1%. But with a strong lineup of software titles, a price cut to Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 console and compelling hardware bundles, NPD is expecting a positive 2015 holiday season, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in statement.The current generation of video game consoles, led by the PS4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, are outselling the prior generation of game machines, he said."After 23 months on the market, combined PS4 and Xbox One sales are 40% higher than the combined 23 month totals for PS3 and Xbox 360," Callahan said.Gauging the health of the video game industry from retail sales of new packaged software is difficult because the NPD statistics do not account for the growing percentage of game sales coming from digital downloads.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz sees a turnaround for physical game software sales in October and the holiday shopping season."We currently expect a major double-digit increase in physical sales in October, driven by the launches of 'Halo 5' and 'Assassin's Creed: Syndicate' vs. a year-ago comp that included no major non-sports AAA launches," Creutz said in a research report Tuesday. "Currently we expect sales in the holiday window to be roughly flat, with the year finishing in slightly positive territory."Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report that the installed base of current-generation game systems is now big enough, at about 40 million units, "to drive sustainable software growth on a quarterly basis."

U.S. teens continue to show strong interest in owning the latest generation video game consoles, which bodes well for game publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA), Piper Jaffray said late Tuesday.

In its semiannual teen survey, Piper Jaffray interviewed 9,400 teenagers nationwide, of which more than 7,500 are video game players. Of those video game-playing teens, 73% own a Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One or Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 or intend to get one. That's up from 70% in the spring and 67% in fall 2014.
The survey revealed that 39% now own a PS4 or Xbox One, up from 37% in the spring and 26% last fall.

Uptake of the latest consoles "is at the highest level we have seen, reinforcing our expectation for a much more rapid pace than prior-gen" consoles, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Tuesday. The rising interest in the newest consoles is a "clear positive" for game publishers Activision, EA and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), as well as specialty retailer GameStop (GME), he said.

The current-generation console game cycle will be aided by some highly anticipated games such as Activision's "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," EA's "Star Wars: Battlefront" and Microsoft's "Halo 5: Guardians."

"We believe the combination of next-gen console uptake and a robust lineup of AAA titles will lead to sustainable software growth through second-half 2015 and into 2016," Olson said. He rates the stocks of Activision, EA, Take-Two and GameStop as overweight.

The fall survey found that 61% of teen gamers purchase pre-owned video games, creeping down from 62% in the spring and 63% last fall. GameStop remains the top place to buy used games with 53% share, up from 48% in the spring. Amazon.com (AMZN) is a distant second at 17% share.

However, the used-game market is being affected by the trend toward digital downloads. The fall survey found that 37% of teens said they expect half or more of their video game purchases to be digital, full-game downloads this year, a significant increase from 19% in the spring.
About 79% of teen gamers play games on their smartphones or tablets compared with 81% in the spring and 80% last fall.
While the percentage of mobile gamers is relatively stable, the number who are paying for virtual goods when playing a mobile game has been on the upswing, Piper Jaffray said.

In its survey, 24% of teens who play mobile games said they spend money in game vs. 21% in the spring, 22% last fall and 18% in spring 2014. This is good news for the free-to-play business models of mobile game publishers like Glu Mobile (GLUU) and King Digital Entertainment (KING).

Teens cool with Apple, but with GoPro they can't even

XApple (AAPL) just confirmed its self-driving car plans, but don't expect to see Apple logos on the road next to Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) cars, says one analyst."What it sounds like is, you know, they're going to focus primarily on the technology behind the car vs. actually building an Apple Car — which might disappoint some Apple fans that there won't be a car running around with an Apple logo on it, but I think that's probably the right strategy for them," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson told Investor's Business Daily at E3 2017.Olson said his firm has spoken with many investors about Apple getting into the car business, and the feeling is that this is a good "happy medium" for Apple to get in on the software side of things.For more E3 coverage and the latest from Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox, Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), Facebook (FB) and others, head to IBD's E3 news hub or check out our live-streamed videos on Facebook.RELATED:Apple Finally Confirms Its Worst-Kept SecretVideo Game Stocks Hot, But This One Is A BuyGM Triples Self-Driving Test Fleet But Look Who's On Its Tail

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) received at least nine price-target hikes from Wall Street firms after delivering better-than-expected March-quarter results Tuesday.Take-Two stock soared 6.7% to 77.73 on the stock market today, hitting a fresh all-time high.Wall Street firms raising their price targets on the stock included Baird, Benchmark, BMO Capital Markets, CFRA, Jefferies, Macquarie, Mizuho Securities, Pacific Crest Securities and Piper Jaffray. All have buy ratings or the equivalent on the stock, except for Baird and CFRA, which rate it as neutral and hold, based on valuation.Analysts shrugged off Take-Two's announcement that it is postponing the release of its Western shooter game "Red Dead Redemption 2" until spring 2018 from this fall."We do not view such a delay negatively, especially with recurring revenue continuing to roll in from 'Grand Theft Auto Online' and 'NBA 2K,' as the company is known to sacrifice release dates for the sake of quality," BMO analyst Gerrick Johnson said in a report.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks includes two video game firms: Activision Blizzard and NetEase.Take-Two's fiscal 2019, which will start on April 1, 2018, is shaping up to be a record year, with the launch of "Red Dead Redemption 2" and a major unannounced title, likely "Borderlands 3," Johnson said.The focus at Take-Two has shifted from big game releases to long-term recurring revenue from major game properties through downloadable content and online services.Video game publishers like Take-Two, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) have been benefiting from the shift to higher-margin digital downloads and away from sales of packaged media.RELATED:Take-Two's Strong Sales, Earnings Ease Pain Of 'Red Dead' Delay

X Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox and Sony (SNE) PlayStation are taking divergent paths when it comes to virtual reality.Microsoft is taking it slow with its new VR-capable console, said Engadget reporter Devindra Hardawar in an interview at E3."I don't blame them," Hardawar told IBD. "I do think the VR market, as exciting as it is for me - general consumers haven't been into it too much. So, Sony was out there early, and their stuff is mostly good but there are some issues. It kind of makes sense for Microsoft to take a step back and make sure they get it right for the living room, so I'm not going to read too much into this yet. And the VR market is still growing."But, he added, the hefty price point will pose a problem for Microsoft this holiday season.Watch the video for the interview, and for more E3 2017 coverage and details on Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) , Facebook (FB) and others, head to IBD's E3 news hub or check out our live-streamed videos on Facebook.

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) early Tuesday appeased investors worried about the delay of its big title "Red Dead Redemption 2" by delivering strong sales and earnings growth in its fiscal fourth quarter. Its stock surged to a record high on the news.New York, N.Y.-based Take-Two earned 89 cents a share, up 85% year over year, on sales of $572 million, up 52%, in its fiscal Q4 ended March 31.The biggest contributors in the quarter were "Grand Theft Auto 5" and "Grand Theft Auto Online," "Mafia 3," "NBA 2K17," "Sid Meier's Civilization 6" and "WWE 2K17."On a non-GAAP basis, Take-Two earned 67 cents a share on sales of $407 million in the March quarter, vs. analyst expectations of 57 cents and $355 million.Take-Two shares soared to a record high of 76.70 in morning trading on the stock market today. In mid-morning trading, the stock was up 6%, near 73.30. Take-Two stock fell 10% in after-hours trading Monday after Take-Two's Rockstar label announced that its highly anticipated Wild West action game "Red Dead Redemption 2" had been delayed from this fall until spring 2018. Analysts said the delay was not a surprise and had been rumored for some time."We attribute this slip to Rockstar's infamous perfectionism and don't think it changes the overall unit sales potential for the game," Jefferies analyst Timothy O'Shea said in a report.Take-Two on Tuesday forecast fiscal 2018 revenue that was well below Wall Street's targets because of the game delay. For its fiscal 2018 ending March 31, Take Two expects adjusted sales of $1.42 billion to $1.52 billion. Analysts were modeling for $2.23 billion.Earlier this month, Electronic Arts (EA) blasted Wall Street's estimates with its Q4 earnings, and Activision Blizzard (ATVI) also obliterated the Street's targets with its Q1 sales and earnings.The delay of "Red Dead Redemption 2" is good news for Activision and EA, because it lessens the competition this holiday season. Big game releases later this year include Activision's "Destiny 2" (Sept. 8) and "Call of Duty: WWII" (Nov. 3) and EA's "Star Wars: Battlefront 2" (Nov. 17).Activision Blizzard stock was up 1%, near 57.70, in morning trading Tuesday. Earlier in the session, it hit a record high of 60.13. Meanwhile, EA stock was up 0.4%, near 108.90.RELATED:Wild West Game Delay Guns Down Take-Two Stock

XFutures for the S&P 500 index, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq 100 edged higher early Wednesday after the major market averages rose Tuesday. Big-cap Dow techs Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) rebounded and helped lift the blue-chip index to a record high. But overall trading activity was below normal after two straight high-volume slides for the Nasdaq.So will the market uptrend, currently under pressure, continue to rebound? Follow the major averages and leading stocks, and read The Big Picture.As for the broader market overnight, Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.2% above fair value. Dow futures were 0.15% higher and S&P 500 futures were up 0.1%.U.S. crude oil futures fell 1% to just below $46 a barrel after the American Petroleum Institute reported surprise builds in crude and gasoline stockpiles. Later today, the Energy Information Administration will release official weekly inventory and production data.Also this morning, the Commerce Department will release retail sales figures for May and the Labor Department will announce the consumer price index. This afternoon the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates for the second time this year.Meanwhile, Nintendo (NTDOY) remains in a buy zone after the Japanese video game giant touted its new Switch console at gamer mecca E3.Nintendo announced upcoming games for its dual-use Switch console, mostly in-house titles. But third-party games will include "FIFA 18" from Electronic Arts (EA). Switch, in tight supply since its March release, is a regular console that you connect to a TV. But it has a detachable tablet screen and portable controllers for on-the-go play.Nintendo shares rose 1.6% to 39.25 in Tuesday stock market trading, still in range from a 38.35 buy point in a cup base going back 11 months. The stock is trading at seven-year highs. Nintendo skyrocketed last July during the "Pokemon Go" frenzy.Microsoft and Sony (SNE) made their video console announcements earlier this week. Microsoft briefly fell back into buy range on Monday, but rebounded from its 50-day line and closed out of the 5% chase zone. Microsoft rose 1.25% Tuesday.Sony is extended from a buy point decisively retaken in late April. Sony shares dipped 0.3% on Tuesday.As for video game makers, Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) are all making E3 news this week as well. But Activision, Electronic Arts and Take-Two shares are well-extended from proper buy points. Activision shares rose 2% on Tuesday, while EA gained 1% and Take-Two 1.1%.Chinese online game portal NetEase (NTES) dipped 1.6% to 301.69, dropping just out of range from a 301.92 buy point. NetEase licenses many games, including Activision Blizzard's "World of Warcraft."Apple is not a video game maker, though several iOS mobile games are being unveiled at E3, with Apple getting its hefty App Store cut. Apple announced a new augmented-reality programming kit at last week's Worldwide Developers Conference, likely foreshadowing AR capabilities for games and other functions in the upcoming iPhone 8.Apple shares rose 0.8%, but closed below their 50-day average for a second straight session.Japan's Nikkei fell 0.1% intraday Wednesday while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 climbed 1.1%. China's Shanghai composite dipped 0.7% after China reported stronger-than-expected industrial production in May, with retail sales growth matching views.In Europe intraday, the major market averages were solidly higher. The U.K.'s FTSE was up 0.5% while Germany's Dax and France's CAC-40 gained 0.8%.RELATED:Rally In Light Volume; Does The Bull Case Still Hold Water?Nintendo Makes Pitch For Switch At E3, Previews New GamesE3 2017: Video Games, Virtual Reality, Entertainment NewsMicrosoft, EA: 2 Leading Tech Stocks Grabbing Early E3 Buzz

Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) shares bit the dust late Monday after the video game publisher announced that its Western shooter game "Red Dead Redemption 2" was delayed until Spring 2018 from this fall."Red Dead Redemption 2" was expected to be the company's biggest video game release this year. It had been scheduled for an October release, well-positioned for the holiday shopping season.The company's Rockstar Games label, which also makes the company's popular "Grand Theft Auto" game series, announced the delay after the market close Monday.Take-Two stock was down over 10% in after-hours trading on the stock market today. During the regular session Monday, shares rose 2.2% to 69.04.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 82, meaning it has outperformed 82% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Take-Two, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."We are very sorry for any disappointment this delay causes, but we are firm believers in delivering a game only when it is ready," the company said in a blog post. " 'Red Dead Redemption 2' is now set to launch Spring 2018 on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. This outlaw epic set across the vast and unforgiving American heartland will be the first Rockstar game created from the ground up for the latest generation of console hardware, and some extra time is necessary to ensure that we can deliver the best experience possible for our fans."New York, N.Y.-based Take-Two is scheduled to report its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday before the market open.Earlier this month, Electronic Arts (EA) blasted Wall Street's estimates with its Q4 earnings, and Activision Blizzard (ATVI) also obliterated the Street's targets with its Q1 sales and earnings.RELATED:Take-Two Takes Three Price-Target Hikes; Stock Near Record High

Stocks opened lower Monday, with the Nasdaq falling 1.3% after Friday's tech plunge. Losses on the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were light in comparison, down 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively.Among the Dow industrials, General Electric (GE) paced the advancers, soaring about 3% after CEO Jeffrey Immelt decided to step down as chairman and CEO. Other gainers include energy components Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), which rose about 1.5% apiece.In early trading, the blue-chip index's laggards were tech components Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT). The iPhone maker was downgraded to neutral by Mizuho, while its price target was lowered to 150 from 160. Shares are under their 50-day for the first time since a January breakout. Apple fell 3.7%, while Microsoft declined 2.6%.FANG stocks were under significant selling pressure for a second consecutive day in the stock market today. Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) all declined at least 2% each. Netflix, the video streaming company, saw the heaviest losses at 4.1%.Among leading stocks, graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) traded down 3.6%, while electric automaker Tesla (TSLA) dropped 1.2%.Video game makers sold off hard in the stock market today ahead of this week's E3 conference. Take-Two (TTWO) and Activision (ATVI) fell over 3% each, while Electronic Arts (EA) declined 3.5%.Among analyst actions, Adobe Systems (ADBE) was downgraded to sell from hold at Pivotal Research Group. Shares dropped 3.5% as the stock pierced its 50-day line for the first time since a January breakout.Action in the IBD 50 was predominantly negative during the Nasdaq's sell-off. Two bright spots were Nutrisystem (NTRI) and New Oriental Education (EDU), rising 1% and 2.6%, respectively.On the downside, losers were rampant. Ichor Holdings (ICHR) plunged over 10%. Cavium (CAVM) and Veeva Systems (VEEV) declined about 6% each.RELATED:Apple Downgraded As iPhone Excitement Is Already Baked In; Adobe CutDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisE3 Show To Set Expectations For Big Holiday Video Game LaunchesGE's Immelt Steps Down, Flannery Moves Up Amid Trian SqueezeFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

Many funds reversed lower along with the broader market, but these two U.S. index ETFs managed to hold gains.Blue chips and small-cap stocks closed Friday with modest advances as tracked by the Dow Jones industrial average and the Russell 2000 index.IShares Russell 2000 (IWM) broke out intraday past a 141.92 flat-base buy point to mark a new high. But it pared its gain to 0.5%, closing just below the entry. It's formed a series of three bases almost right next to each other since December. Before that, IWM rose 10% from a flat-base breakout in November.The fund, launched in May 2000, has attracted $36.6 billion in assets. IWM has lagged the S&P 500 this year through June 8 with a 4.8% gain vs. the benchmark index's 9.7%, according to Morningstar Inc. But its one-year return of 20.8% has outpaced the S&P 500's 17.3%, and the ETF's 15-year average annual return of 9.07% is also ahead at 9.07% vs. 8.11%.Since May 19, IWM's 4% gain has doubled iShares S&P 500's (IVV) gain.Several of the tech names in IWM's top holdings took a beating Friday, including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and Coherent (COHR), which fell about 5% each. But its financial names helped offset some of the losses.SPDR S&P MidCap 400 (MDY) pared its gain to 0.3% Friday to close slightly below a 320.58 flat-base buy point. It had cleared the entry earlier in the session. The ETF started forming the current pattern after a 3% advance from a prior flat base and 7% from the one before.It's up nearly 6% year to date through June 8 and has slightly underperformed the S&P 500 for one-, three- and five-year average annual returns. But it's ahead of the benchmark index for the 10- and 15-year periods with respective returns of 8.2% and 9.8% vs. 7.2% and 8.2% for the S&P 500.The $18.8 billion fund, which was launched in May 1995, counts Everest Re Group (RE), Align Technology (ALGN) and Duke Realty (DRE) among its top holdings. Real estate investment trusts and other financials turned in a solid performance Friday.Moving over to Thursday's ETF picks, the featured pair of gold funds have pulled back from their cup-with-handle buy points as gold prices slid for a third straight session. But they're not too far from their entries. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) and iShares Gold Trust (IAU) are 2% below their respective buy points of 123.17 and 12.54.RELATED:Gilded Gains? Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is satisfying its sweet tooth for acquisitions by buying mobile game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING), best known for "Candy Crush Saga."
Activision announced late Monday that it has agreed to pay $18 in cash per share for London-based King, in a deal worth $5.9 billion. The offer is a 20% premium over King's Friday closing price.
King shares jumped 3.9% to 15.54 on Monday in heavy volume ahead of the acquisition announcement. And King stock was up another 15%, near 18, in early afternoon trading in the stock market today.

Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision plans to fund the deal with $3.6 billion in offshore cash and $2.3 billion in debt financing. Activision ended the third quarter with $4.5 billion in cash and investments, with $870 million held domestically and the rest offshore.

U.S.-based multinational companies are reluctant to repatriate foreign profits because of hefty taxes. U.S. companies bringing home foreign earnings must pay the full U.S. corporate tax rate of 35%, though they get tax credits for payments to foreign governments.
Activision expects the deal to close in spring 2016, subject to approval from government regulators and King shareholders.
Mobile Games Gain

Activision's purchase of King Digital will bolster its position in the fast-growing mobile games market, Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said on a conference call with analysts Tuesday. Activision already is a leader in console and PC video games, with franchises including "Call of Duty," "Skylanders," "Destiny" and "World of Warcraft."

"We think now is the right time to enter mobile gaming in a meaningful way," Kotick said. "Widespread mobile access around the world has opened up significant demand for engaging, fun content that players can enjoy anytime, anywhere."

The mobile games market is worth $36 billion, but it's "extremely fragmented," Kotick said. Other major players include Supercell, Machine Zone, Rovio, Glu Mobile (GLUU), Electronic Arts (EA) and Zynga (ZNGA).

"Acquiring King will solidify Activision Blizzard's position as the world leader in interactive entertainment, positioning the combined company for growth across platforms, audiences, genres and business models," Kotick said.

The acquisition is a "creative, tax-efficient way to use its offshore cash as it enters the fast-growing mobile gaming market in earnest," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a research report Tuesday. King's sales, however, are declining as its "Candy Crush" franchise matures and as it faces the "daunting task" of trying to replicate that success, Pitz said.
King's revenue has fallen on a year-over-year basis for four straight quarters, and earnings per share have dropped in three of those four quarters.

King is scheduled to report third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect King to earn 37 cents a share excluding items, down 34% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $455 million, down 13%.
Activision Earnings Rise
Meanwhile, Activision reported Q3 earnings Monday that soundly beat Wall Street's estimates.

Activision earned 21 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.04 billion in the September quarter. Analysts were looking for EPS of 15 cents on sales of $950 million. On a year-over-year basis, Activision's earnings per share rose 9%, and sales fell 11%.
Analysts are divided on whether Activision got a bargain or overpaid for King.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz called the acquisition "an absolute steal for Activision." The purchase "immediately vaults them to being one of the top mobile gaming companies in the world."

The timing of the sale is puzzling, because King is on the cusp of launching another "Candy Crush" sequel and has three more games in regional testing, including "Farm Heroes," its second-biggest franchise, Creutz said.

"Success by these games could have returned the company to a top-line growth profile, which we think would have reaped benefits for King shares, given the company's inherently high profitability," Creutz said. "We can only surmise that perhaps the management team and key investors were tired of being spurned by the market as a public company and wanted to be able to totally focus on game creation."
Mike Wade, a professor at the IMD business school of Switzerland, said Activision's purchase price overvalues King. "To me, this sounds very expensive," he said in a note.

Activision's purchase of King could pave the way for more mergers and acquisitions in the gaming sector, Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi said in a report. He noted that Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), with $1 billion in cash on hand, could be a buyer.
Evercore ISI analyst Mike Swierczek agreed. Large media conglomerates such as Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) could be potential acquirers of mobile games companies, he said in a report.

Activision stock was up 7% in afternoon trading, near 37. Glu Mobile stock was up 4.6%, and Zynga added 3%, on speculation that they could be acquisition targets.Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is satisfying its sweet tooth for acquisitions by buying mobile game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING), best known for "Candy Crush Saga."Activision announced late Monday that it has agreed to pay $18 in cash per share for London-based King, in a deal worth $5.9 billion. "To me, this sounds very expensive," he said in a note.Activision's purchase of King could pave the way for more mergers and acquisitions in the gaming sector, Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi said in a report. He noted that Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), with $1 billion in cash on hand, could be a buyer.Evercore ISI analyst Mike Swierczek agreed. Large media conglomerates such as Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) could be potential acquirers of mobile games companies, he said in a report.Activision stock was up 7% in afternoon trading, near 37. Glu Mobile stock was up 4.6%, and Zynga added 3%, on speculation that they could be acquisition targets.

Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is satisfying its sweet tooth for acquisitions by buying mobile game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING), best known for "Candy Crush Saga."Activision announced late Monday that it has agreed to pay $18 in cash per share for London-based King, in a deal worth $5.9 billion. The offer is a 20% premium over King's Friday closing price.King shares jumped 3.9% to 15.54 on Monday in heavy volume ahead of the acquisition announcement. And King stock was up another 15%, near 18, in early afternoon trading in the stock market today.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision plans to fund the deal with $3.6 billion in offshore cash and $2.3 billion in debt financing. Activision ended the third quarter with $4.5 billion in cash and investments, with $870 million held domestically and the rest offshore.U.S.-based multinational companies are reluctant to repatriate foreign profits because of hefty taxes. U.S. companies bringing home foreign earnings must pay the full U.S. corporate tax rate of 35%, though they get tax credits for payments to foreign governments.Activision expects the deal to close in spring 2016, subject to approval from government regulators and King shareholders.Mobile Games GainActivision's purchase of King Digital will bolster its position in the fast-growing mobile games market, Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said on a conference call with analysts Tuesday. Activision already is a leader in console and PC video games, with franchises including "Call of Duty," "Skylanders," "Destiny" and "World of Warcraft.""We think now is the right time to enter mobile gaming in a meaningful way," Kotick said. "Widespread mobile access around the world has opened up significant demand for engaging, fun content that players can enjoy anytime, anywhere."The mobile games market is worth $36 billion, but it's "extremely fragmented," Kotick said. Other major players include Supercell, Machine Zone, Rovio, Glu Mobile (GLUU), Electronic Arts (EA) and Zynga (ZNGA)."Acquiring King will solidify Activision Blizzard's position as the world leader in interactive entertainment, positioning the combined company for growth across platforms, audiences, genres and business models," Kotick said.The acquisition is a "creative, tax-efficient way to use its offshore cash as it enters the fast-growing mobile gaming market in earnest," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a research report Tuesday. King's sales, however, are declining as its "Candy Crush" franchise matures and as it faces the "daunting task" of trying to replicate that success, Pitz said.King's revenue has fallen on a year-over-year basis for four straight quarters, and earnings per share have dropped in three of those four quarters.King is scheduled to report third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect King to earn 37 cents a share excluding items, down 34% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $455 million, down 13%.Activision Earnings RiseMeanwhile, Activision reported Q3 earnings Monday that soundly beat Wall Street's estimates.Activision earned 21 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.04 billion in the September quarter. Analysts were looking for EPS of 15 cents on sales of $950 million. On a year-over-year basis, Activision's earnings per share rose 9%, and sales fell 11%.Analysts are divided on whether Activision got a bargain or overpaid for King.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz called the acquisition "an absolute steal for Activision." The purchase "immediately vaults them to being one of the top mobile gaming companies in the world."The timing of the sale is puzzling, because King is on the cusp of launching another "Candy Crush" sequel and has three more games in regional testing, including "Farm Heroes," its second-biggest franchise, Creutz said."Success by these games could have returned the company to a top-line growth profile, which we think would have reaped benefits for King shares, given the company's inherently high profitability," Creutz said. "We can only surmise that perhaps the [PAGE[management]] team and key investors were tired of being spurned by the market as a public company and wanted to be able to totally focus on game creation."Mike Wade, a professor at the IMD business school of Switzerland, said Activision's purchase price overvalues King. "To me, this sounds very expensive," he said in a note.Activision's purchase of King could pave the way for more mergers and acquisitions in the gaming sector, Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi said in a report. He noted that Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), with $1 billion in cash on hand, could be a buyer.Evercore ISI analyst Mike Swierczek agreed. Large media conglomerates such as Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) could be potential acquirers of mobile games companies, he said in a report.Activision stock was up 7% in afternoon trading, near 37. Glu Mobile stock was up 4.6%, and Zynga added 3%, on speculation that they could be acquisition targets.

After hitting a record high on Monday, video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) hit the pause button Tuesday. Activision stock was down a fraction in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Its shares hit an all-time high of 31.65 on Monday.
Year to date, Activision stock is up 56%.

The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company is benefiting from the sweet spot of the console upgrade cycle and the shift to digital downloads. These trends have lifted other major game publishers as well, including Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).
IBD's Computer Software-Gaming sector ranks No. 22 out of 197 industry groups.
Last week, Activision announced the successful launch of "Destiny: The Taken King," the latest chapter in the "Destiny" science-fiction game saga.
Up next for Activision is the release of "Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5," the first game in the skateboarding franchise in eight years. It is set for release on Sept. 29.

The reviews for "Pro Skater 5" aren't out yet, but Forbes contributing writer Paul Tassi said the game preview videos are worrisome. "I've just never seen a promotional campaign for a game to make something look this bad," he wrote.
Activision's biggest upcoming game title is "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3." The first-person shooter game is set for release on Nov. 6.
Baird analyst Colin Sebastian on Tuesday reiterated his outperform rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 36 from 30.

"Overall, we remain positive, with a successful launch of the Destiny expansion pack, a stronger 2016 product slate, and opportunities for incremental growth in 2017 and beyond," Sebastian said in a research note.

E-sports and other emerging business areas could provide expanded opportunities for Activision, he said. The other areas include mobile and free-to-play games, digital content sales and virtual reality games.
E-sports could become a meaningful revenue contributor within two to three years, he said.

Virtual reality should start to gain consumer adoption in 2016, Sebastian said. Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus, Sony (SNE) PlayStation and other companies are aggressively pursuing the VR hardware market.
RELATED:
Disney Joins Google, Facebook In Virtual Reality Wars
Virtual Reality Games Face Real Market Challenges

Electronic Arts (EA) scored with "Madden NFL 16" in August, but overall video game sales were tackled for a loss last month.

This year's Madden pro football game, released on Aug. 25, was the top-selling video game at U.S. retail stores in August, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. It was followed by Microsoft 's (MSFT) "Minecraft" and "Gears of War: Ultimate Edition" in second and third places, respectively.
Overall sales of video game hardware, software and accessories dipped 2% year over year to $548 million, NPD said.
Sales of new, packaged game software dropped 10% to $208 million. Game console sales slid 2% to $191 million. Game accessory sales were a bright spot, rising 12% to $150 million, NPD said.

Sales of game software for the current generation of consoles, including Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, were up 34%, but couldn't offset the decline in portable and older generation console game sales, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.
Current (eighth generation) consoles represented 68% of software sales in August, compared with 61% of sales in July, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday.

The installed base of current-generation consoles (about 40 million units) "is now large enough to drive sustainable software growth," he said. "We expect that 2015 and 2016 will be the equivalent to 2007 and 2008 during the prior console cycle; both were years that experienced significant industry software growth, following several years of decline or limited growth in the space."
Olson reiterated his overweight ratings on game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI), EA and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), and specialty retailer GameStop (GME).

The decline in overall game product sales at retail in August followed two months of increased sales on a year-over-year basis. NPD's figures include only new physical-game sales. They don't include digital sales, such as game downloads, smartphone games and subscriptions, or used-game sales and rentals.
For that reason, it's getting tough to gauge the health of the video game industry from the NPD figures, Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a report Friday.

Retail sales of the latest Madden game were down roughly 10% from the comparable five-day sales window last year, Creutz said. But the percentage of Madden units sold digitally is increasing, possibly offsetting the retail decline, he said.
Creutz maintained his outperform ratings on Activision, EA and Take-Two.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and United Continental (UAL) are being added to the S&P 500. They're replacing two buyouts: Pall (PLL) is being acquired by Danaher (DHR), and Hospira (HSP) is being bought by Pfizer (PFE).Here's what you need to know about the two new additions:Activision Blizzard earns a 95 IBD Composite Rating. Earlier this month, the video game publisher reported better-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings, which shot up 117%.Its big-name games include "Call of Duty," "World of Warcraft" and "Guitar Hero." Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) are two of its peers, and EA is a fellow S&P 500 component.Activision shares gapped up 5.8% in giant volume in the stock market today, shaking off the sell-off and hitting an all-time high of 30 intraday. The stock has risen about 47% this year.United Continental has an 85 IBD Composite Rating. The carrier met analyst expectations when it reported earnings a month ago.The airline industry group has come under pressure lately amid a Justice Department investigation into airfare price collusion.Peers Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) are already members of the S&P 500.United shares popped 6.7% in fast turnover, retaking their 50-day moving average. But the stock is still trading below its 200-day line and is more than 20% below its late January peak.Activision is set to join the index after the close Friday, while United Continental will be added after the close Wednesday.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.

X Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 rose early Tuesday following a suicide bombing at an Ariana Grande concert in the U.K. that left 22 people dead and 59 injured. Several key earnings reports Tuesday may move leading sectors Tuesday morning, with Momo (MOMO) and Toll Brothers (TOL) already topping forecasts.Stock futures, which fell slightly overnight, were modestly higher Tuesday morning. Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average were 0.2% above fair value. S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures climbed nearly 0.2% higher.In Asia trading Tuesday, Japan's Nikkei slid 0.3%. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 was down 0.2% and China's Shanghai composite dipped 0.45%. In European trade intraday, the FTSE 100 rose 0.2%, Germany's Dax 0.5% and France's CAC-40 0.7%.During Monday's session, the Nasdaq composite rose 0.8% in stock market trading, moving within 1% of a new record high. The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average both regained their 50-day moving averages, climbing 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively.Netflix (NFLX) celebrated its 15th anniversary as a public company on Monday. That followed a 20-year IPO anniversary for Amazon.com (AMZN) and a five-year anniversary for Facebook (FB) earlier this month. (Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) came public in August 2004.)Looking ahead to Tuesday, hot Chinese internet stock Momo, video game maker Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and luxury builder Toll Brothers are due to report earnings before the opening bell.Momo advanced 1.4% to 43.42, paring initial gains in early trading after crushing Q1 views. Toll Bros. reported better-than-expected Q2 EPS and sales growth, sending its shares up 2.55% to 39.All three leading stocks are extended from proper buy points, but Momo and Toll results could affect related stocks such as NetEase (NTES) and Lennar (LEN) that are consolidating near buy points.Meanwhile, Take-Two Interactive shares tumbled 8% in early trading after its Rockstar Games label confirmed late Monday that the release of "Red Dead Redemption 2" would be delayed from this fall to Spring 2018.Netflix came public on May 22, 2002. The IPO price was 15 (1.07 split adjusted). Since then shares have skyrocketed 14,568%.Much as Facebook had a costly, expensive shift to mobile, Netflix transitioned from its DVD-by-mail origins to streaming, which substantially raised content costs. But booming subscriber growth, including a near-global expansion, and more homegrown content have offset that.Increasingly, Netflix is seen as a "necessity" rather than a luxury. Even as Amazon Prime Video and Hulu have become more-viable rivals, many Americans are signing up for multiple streaming services, rather than picking just one.Netflix has made a big bet on exclusive comedy specials in 2017. Some analysts have speculated that Netflix could decide to expand into exclusive sports content. Facebook, Amazon and Twitter (TWTR) have ventured more into sports (Facebook has begun live-streaming a Major League Baseball game every Friday, with Amazon recently getting the rights to the NFL's "Thursday Night Football," taking over from Twitter.)Netflix shares rose 0.1% to 157.16 in Monday stock market trading, up 27% so far in 2017. The stock hit a record high of 161.78 on May 15.RELATED:The Big Picture: IBD 50 Jumps 1.3% As Bulls Take ChargeThese Top Housing Stocks Are Near Buy Points: Investing Action PlanIf You Think Netflix, Amazon Disrupted Hollywood, You'll Love Snap, FacebookNetflix: Still A Hot Tech Play Or A Media Stock That Acts Like Tech?

Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), publisher of the "Grand Theft Auto" and "NBA 2K" video games, received three price-target hikes on Friday, just ahead of its quarterly earnings report next week.Benchmark reiterated its buy rating on Take-Two and raised its price target to 77 from 69. Mizuho Securities kept its buy rating and upped its price target to 75 from 60. Wedbush stuck with its neutral rating, but increased its price target to 65 from 48.Take-Two shares fell 1.5% to 67.58 at the close on the stock market today. The stock hit a record high of 70.53 on Tuesday.The New York, N.Y.-based company is scheduled to report its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday before the market open.Analysts expect Take-Two to earn 57 cents a share excluding items, up 24% year over year, on sales of $355.4 million, up 4%, for the fourth quarter.For the current quarter, Wall Street is modeling the company to lose 18 cents a share on sales of $255.8 million, compared with a year-earlier loss of 34 cents a share and sales of $272.6 million.Like rival publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA), Take-Two is benefiting from the shift to high-margin digital downloads and away from packaged media sales. It also hopes to capitalize on the emerging e-sports professional video gaming market.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software ranks No. 7 out of 13 stocks in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two's guidance for the current quarter and full fiscal year is likely to disappoint because management gives conservative numbers, Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said in a report.The fall release of Take-Two's western-themed video game "Red Dead Redemption 2" is expected to be one of the year's hottest titles.A recent survey of gamers by Piper Jaffray was especially positive for "Red Dead Redemption 2" and Activision's "Call of Duty: WWII.""We expect Take-Two to beat consensus fiscal Q4 estimates after the close on Tuesday," Mizuho analyst San Phan said in a report. "Looking ahead, we see solid growth for fiscal 2018 with 'RDR 2' and strong levels of profitability."RELATED:Electronic Arts Gets Caution Flag After Huge Stock GainNetEase Handily Beats Earnings Views, Stock Jumps After Hours

The rapidly growing e-sports market is likely to be a hot topic at next week's E3 video game conference in Los Angeles, and one broker thinks the stock plays in that realm to watch heading into the show are Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Facebook (FB) and Microsoft (MSFT).About 190 million people watch e-sports regularly, up 19% from 160 million in 2016, Pacific Crest Securities said in a note to clients. Global e-sports revenue is expected to climb 46% this year to $600 million, including advertising, sponsorships, media rights, merchandise and tickets, it said."Although eSports is still a frontier market, we believe its high growth, large audience, and attractive demographics warrant investor attention," Pacific Crest analyst Evan Wingren said in the report. E-sports will create opportunities for video game publishers, streaming video services, and hardware makers, Wingren said.Among the major game publishers, he likes Activision best. He rates the stock outperform with a price target of 60. Activision stock rose a fraction to 60.55 on the stock market today.Activision stock "is the most direct public investment in eSports that you can make, in our view." The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company owns the "Overwatch," "Hearthstone" and "Call of Duty" franchises, which are already popular in competitive gaming.Other publishers targeting e-sports include Electronic Arts (EA), mostly through its FIFA soccer game, and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), through its "NBA 2K" basketball game.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks includes two video game companies: Activision and NetEase.The leading publishers in e-sports now are Activision, Tencent (TCEHY)-owned Riot Games with "League of Legends," and privately held Valve with "Counter-Strike: Global Offense" and "Dota 2."Wingren thinks Facebook has a chance to take on Amazon.com (AMZN)-owned Twitch as a streaming video platform for e-sports tournaments. Twitch is the market leader in the segment with about 10 million daily active users. Alphabet's (GOOGL) YouTube is another big player in the e-sports streaming space.Finally, Microsoft is best positioned among the console makers to become a major player in e-sports, Wingren said. It has its Xbox game consoles, Xbox Live service, first-party games and royalties on third-party publisher sales on its platform, he said.RELATED:NetEase Hits Record High Despite Sell Rating; E3 Show On Tap'Star Wars,' 'Call of Duty,' Scorpio Vying To Be Top Guns At E3 Show

After rising 13% on Wednesday, Electronic Arts (EA) stock took a breather on Thursday after BMO Capital Markets raised the caution flag.BMO analyst Gerrick Johnson reiterated a market perform rating on EA stock based on valuation, but he increased his price target to 100 from 80.EA shares were down 0.4% to close at 108.58 on the stock market today. The stock hit an all-time high of 110.61 in intraday trading Wednesday.Late Tuesday, the video game publisher posted fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that crushed Wall Street estimates on in-line sales.EA reported adjusted earnings of 85 cents a share, up 69% year over year, on sales of $1.09 billion, up 18%, in the quarter ended March 31. Analysts expected 74 cents and $1.09 billion.Under generally accepted accounting principles, EA earned $1.81 a share, down 35%, on revenue of $1.53 billion, up 17%, in the fiscal fourth quarter.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts has an IBD Composite Rating of 86, meaning it has outperformed 86% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on EA, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.EA's results in the March quarter were helped by continued strong sales of its World War I shooter game "Battlefield 1" and growth in pro soccer game "FIFA 17.""We are hesitant to recommend shares given current valuation," Johnson said. "But, as we have quickly come to learn, as long as the words 'eSports' and 'digital transition' are part of the earnings commentary, these multiples can stay at lofty levels, and perhaps continue to expand, for an extended period of time."EA and rivals Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) are benefiting from the industry shift to higher-margin digital game downloads and the emerging e-sports professional video game market.RELATED:Electronic Arts Jumps Into Hyperspace With Q4 Earnings BeatActivision Blizzard Shoots To New High On Upbeat Earnings'Grand Theft Auto' Video Game Publisher Gets Price-Target Hike

Electronic Arts (EA) saw its stock jump into hyperspace on Wednesday after the publisher of video games like "Star Wars: Battlefront" blasted Wall Street's estimates with its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings.EA stock rocketed 12.65% to 108.16 on the stock market today, hitting an all-time high of 110.61 intradayRival video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) also notched fresh record highs Wednesday. Activision rose 2.5% while Take-Two leapt 5.5%.Redwood City, Calif.-based EA late Tuesday reported adjusted earnings of 85 cents a share, up 69% year over year, on sales of $1.09 billion, up 18%, in the quarter ended March 31. Analysts expected 74 cents and $1.09 billion.EA's results were helped by robust digital sales from its "Battlefield 1" and "FIFA" game franchises, which offset weak sales of "Mass Effect: Andromeda."EA stock got price target increases from at least nine investment banks. They included Baird, Benchmark, Credit Suisse, Jefferies, Mizuho, Pacific Crest Securities, Piper Jaffray, UBS and Wedbush."We expect significant growth for the foreseeable future driven by cost discipline, digital sales growth, and evergreen franchises including Battlefield, the Star Wars games, and several sports titles," Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said in a report. He reiterated his outperform rating on EA and raised his price target to 116 from 95.Mizuho analyst San Phan sees several catalysts ahead for EA. They include the company's EA Play event alongside the E3 games conference, a robust release slate including "Star Wars: Battlefront 2" as well as new games in the "Need for Speed," "UFC" and "NBA Live" franchises.Phan maintained his buy rating on EA and upped his price target to 115 from 94.RELATED:Electronic Arts Jumps On Q4 Earnings Beat, Stock Buyback Plan'Grand Theft Auto' Video Game Publisher Gets Price-Target HikeActivision Blizzard Shoots To New High On Upbeat Earnings

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) late Thursday easily beat Wall Street estimates for the June quarter, and it raised its guidance for the full year.But EA stock was down 3% in after-hours trading after the earnings release, as the company's guidance disappointed investors. During the regular session, EA rose a fraction to 72.30. EA shares hit an all-time high of 75.10 on July 21.The Redwood City, Calif.-based company earned 15 cents a share excluding items on sales of $693 million in its fiscal Q1 ended June 30. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 3 cents and $652 million.On a year-over-year basis, EPS fell 21% and sales dropped 11%.EA CFO Blake Jorgensen credited strong catalog game sales and better-than-expected business in digital live service for the Q1 beat.Top-selling games in the quarter included cops-and-robbers shootout game "Battlefield Hardline" and soccer game "FIFA 15."For the current fiscal 2016, EA raised its revenue guidance by $50 million to $4.45 billion and non-GAAP EPS guidance by 10 cents a share to $2.85 a share. Those targets, however, are below where analysts have been forecasting.Wall Street had been modeling EA to earn $2.87 cents a share ex items on sales of $4.48 billion.For the current quarter, EA is targeting EPS of 40 cents a share minus items on sales of $1.075 billion. Both are below Wall Street's outlook, which had been modeling 67 cents and $1.12 billion for the September quarter.Electronic Arts is the first of the three big U.S. independent game publishers to report June-quarter results. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is scheduled to report its second-quarter results on Tuesday. Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) will follow with its fiscal first-quarter results on Aug. 10.The video game software sector ranks No. 10 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The sector is benefiting from the console upgrade cycle hitting its sweet spot. After a period of investment in new game hardware, gamers are spending their cash on new game software.RELATED:Batman drives video game sales higher in June.

Reporting strong revenue and earnings growth is important. Growth that tops estimates is even better. Today's IBD Screen Of The Day is Estimate Beaters, companies such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) whose actual profit exceeded projections in the prior quarter.The list includes a pair of top-rated video game makers that are burning up the charts, racking up points with investors.Activision BlizzardThe Los Angeles area-based game maker Activision Blizzard built its reputation on favorites such as "Call of Duty," a war-themed franchise that, as of April, had sold more than 175 million copies and enjoyed more than 40 million monthly active players.It's also the parent of "World of Warcraft," the world's most popular massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG).Both games have grossed more than $10 billion each. Activision Blizzard continues to roll out new games including "Destiny," which debuted last September.In the last quarter, Activision Blizzard beat analysts' earnings consensus by 128.6%.On July 14, its stock climbed above a nearly month-long 7% deep flat base with a 26.19 buy point. It's continued rising in the week since, closing at 26.25 Monday, up 1.7% for the day, then kept rising another 1% after hours.Take-Two Interactive SoftwareNew York-based Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) has a different vibe. It's sold an estimated 250 million copies of its fast driving, hot car, gangster-themed game franchise "Grand Theft Auto," according to gaming site IGN. That's led to similars in its portfolio including "L.A. Noire" and "Red Dead Redemption."It's also a leader in sports games with basketball-themed "NBA 2K14," pro wrestling-themed "WWE 2K14" and others.Take-Two Interactive Software beat fiscal Q4 earnings estimates by 81.5%.Its stock rose 0.7% Monday to an all-time high at 31.35 in trading in the stock market today. That was its seventh straight higher close. Take Two has a 93 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 93% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Video game maker Electronic Arts (EA) knocked out Street views by 400% last week when it delivered per-share earnings of 15 cents, above views for 3 cents. Can Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) do the same when they report quarterly results?
Today's Screen of the Day, Estimate Beaters, takes a look at companies that beat earnings estimates by a wide margin.
Activision Blizzard
The publisher behind the "Call of Duty" franchise, "World of Warcraft" and "Guitar Hero," among other titles, reports after the close today, Aug. 4.

Activision's earnings leveled up past analyst estimates by 128.6% in Q1. Adjusted Q2 profit more than doubled to 13 cents a share, beating estimates by 5 cents or 62.5%. Adjusted revenue climbed 15% to $759 million, well above views for $665.5 million.
Shares rose slightly in after-hours trading in the stock market today. The stock broke out of a flat base with 26.19 buy point in mid-July but struggled to remain in buy territory.
The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 90, which means it has outperformed 90% of stocks on a mix of technical and fundamental factors, including earnings and revenue growth.
Take-Two Interactive
Take-Two, which has the "Grand Theft Auto" and "NBA" franchises in its portfolio, beat consensus views by 81.5% in its most recently reported quarter.

When the company reports on Aug. 10, fiscal Q1 results are expected to swing to a profit of 36 cents a share from last year's per-share loss of 14 cents. Revenue is seen jumping 132% to $351.1 million.

The stock, which has a 93 Composite Rating, cleared a 28.82 buy point in late June from a cup-with-handle base, but pulled back to 27.01 before reigniting its climb. Shares were up 1% Tuesday, well above its 50-day line. The stock is now extended past buy range.
Electronic Arts

Fans of video games and Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars" alike are anticipating EA's Nov. 17 release date of "Star Wars Battlefront," which comes about a month before the theatrical release of "Star Wars: Episode VII — The Force Awakens." The game will be available on theSony (SNE) PlayStation 4, the Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One and Origin for PC.
Another big title, "Need for Speed," has a Nov. 3 release.
Shares ticked up 0.5%. The stock has an 88 Composite Rating and has been steadily trading above its 50-day line after finding support in late April.
While it beat estimates by 400%, EA's outlook disappointed.
The company guided for 40 cents EPS on $1.075 billion in revenue for the current quarter, below views for EPS of 67 cents and sales of $1.12 billion.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) shares tried to break out of a base Wednesday after Jefferies upgraded the video game publisher's stock to buy. Jefferies says it's broadly positive on the video game sector following the Electronic Entertainment Expo last week in LA. The analyst said video game makers are starting to benefit from the console upgrade cycle and the shift to…

In contrast to their Xbox-playing brethren, women constitute as much as 70% of the smartphone and tablet gaming audience. But the volatile mobile market, marked by few paying customers and even fewer smash hits, has yet to properly tap into this valuable demographic, say some analysts. Women could bring some stability and an influx of revenue to this lopsided boom-bust…

Video game publishers are starting to benefit from the console upgrade cycle hitting the sweet spot and the shift to digital distribution, investment bank Jefferies said Wednesday.Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said he is broadly positive on the video game sector following the annual E3 trade show last week in Los Angeles.Pitz on Wednesday upgraded his ratings on game publishers Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) to buy from hold. He also has a buy rating on Activision Blizzard (ATVI).Pitz sees "two powerful, multiyear tailwinds" for the sector: faster-than-expected sales of next-generation consoles and the transition to digital distribution and other digital revenue streams.He expects the installed base of the latest consoles, specifically Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, to reach 48 million to 49 million by the end of 2015, two years after they launched. By comparison, it took the previous generation consoles, Sony's PS3 and Microsoft's Xbox 360, 3.5 years to hit the same milestone of roughly 50 million consoles sold, he said.The installed base of current consoles could approach 100 million units by year-end 2017, he said.Another positive for game publishers is the move to digital revenue. Publishers get higher profit margins on games sold as downloads than ones sold as packaged media in retail stores."Today, around 15%-20% of new games are digitally downloaded, up from low single digits two years ago, and up to 40% of catalog titles are downloaded," Pitz said. "We expect the percentage of downloads to continue to rise, and the objections (large file sizes, can't resell a download, some people don't have credit cards) will be resolved over time. This is a very positive trend for publishers given gross margin for digital downloads can be 10 to 20 percentage points higher than retail copies of the same game."Looking at specific publishers, Pitz said EA's multiyear game pipeline is "the best we've ever seen (from the company), starting this holiday with 'Star Wars Battlefront.'"He raised his price target on EA stock to 80 from 58. EA stock was up 1.6%, near 68, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Pitz upped his price target on Take-Two to 35 from 29. Take-Two stock was up more than 2%, near 29, in afternoon trading Wednesday.Pitz has a price target of 26 on Activision. Activision stock was up a fraction near 25.50 in afternoon trading Wednesday.RELATED:E3 2015 Video Game News.

Shares of "Grand Theft Auto" video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) are a steal ahead of the company's fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report, investment bank Piper Jaffray said Monday.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Take-Two Interactive stock and raised his price target to 77 from 66. He sees potential upside in Take-Two's fiscal fourth-quarter results based on "Grand Theft Auto Online" and "NBA 2K" digital revenue."We recommend owning TTWO into a solid quarter and ahead of growing anticipation for the 'Red Dead Redemption 2' launch in the fall," Olson said in a note to clients.Olson also expects Take-Two to provide its usual conservative guidance when it gives its initial fiscal 2018 outlook.Take-Two shares were down 0.55% to 65.06 on the stock market today. In intraday trading Monday, Take-Two stock hit a record high of 65.84.Take-Two is scheduled to report fiscal fourth-quarter earnings after the market close on May 23. Analysts expect Take-Two to earn an adjusted 57 cents a share, up 24% year over year, on sales of $355.2 million, up 4%.For the current quarter, Wall Street is modeling Take-Two to lose 20 cents a share vs. a year-ago loss of 34 cents, on sales of $243.5 million, down 11%.Meanwhile, rival video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) received two more price-target hikes following its big first-quarter sales and earnings beat last Thursday.Stifel maintained its buy rating on Activision and upped its price target to 60 from 59. BMO Capital Markets kept its market perform rating and raised its price target to 47 from 42. BMO analyst Gerrick Johnson is neutral on the stock based on valuation.Activision stock rose 0.3% to 53.99. It hit an all-time high of 54.75 on Friday.On Friday, Activision received price target increases from at least six investment banks.IBD'S TAKE: Activision is one of two video game stocks on the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks. The other is China-based NetEase.A third major video game publisher, Electronic Arts (EA), is scheduled to release its fiscal fourth-quarter results after the market close Tuesday.Analysts expect EA to earn 75 cents a share excluding items, up 50%, on sales of $1.09 billion, up 18%, in the March quarter.Electronic Arts dipped 0.1% to 95.67, hitting a record high intraday.RELATED:Activision Blizzard Shoots To New High On Upbeat Earnings

The S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite hit record highs on Thursday, completing a quick recovery from the May 17 market plunge as FANG stocks Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) led the way. Oil prices, which had been steadily rising ahead of OPEC's key meeting, tumbled after the cartel extended production cuts. Meanwhile, Best Buy (BBY) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were among the few retailers to defy the sector sell-off with strong earnings and share gains. Ford (F) ousted its CEO amid woes for the auto sector.The S&P 500 rose 1.4% and the Nasdaq 2.1%, both hitting record highs. The Dow advanced 1.3% Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) rose strongly to new highs, with Amazon and Alphabet nearly hitting the 1,000 price level. Oil prices retreated after OPEC extended but didn't deepen production curbs, leaving intact a status quo that encourages shale producers. Best Buy (BBY) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) soared to record highs as they prove to be Amazon-resilient, while Lowe's (LOW) and Tiffany (TIF) struggled. Red-hot Chinese social media and live-streaming video app Momo (MOMO) cooled off despite crushing views.At its meeting Thursday, OPEC extended production cuts through March 2018 but didn't deepen output curbs as some had speculated, while keeping Libya and Nigeria exempt for the foreseeable future even as their output rises. Oil prices tumbled 4.8% that day, wiping out gains made in the weeks leading up to the meeting. On Wednesday, EIA data showed U.S. oil inventories fell for the seventh consecutive week, while production rebounded from its first dip in three months. After a Friday rebound, U.S. crude futures closed the week down 1.8% to $49.80 a barrel.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) posted a beat-and-raise Q1 that surpassed expectations, sending shares jumping to an all-time high Friday. The specialty beauty retailer's same-store sales growth of 14.3% defied conventional wisdom about traditional sellers and beat consensus for 11% comps. Profit rose 32% to $1.91 a share on 22.5% revenue growth to $1.31 billion. E-commerce sales popped 70.9%.Costco (COST) beat on both the top and bottom lines as same-store sales rose 5%, sending shares upward Friday morning. The membership warehouse is upping its annual fee next week. Dollar Tree (DLTR) fell short of views by a penny with 98 cents EPS and met sales forecasts for $5.29 billion. Comps edged up 0.5%. Outlook for Q2 was light. Burlington Stores (BURL) EPS beat by 9 cents though sales of $1.35 billion were just a hair short of estimates. The midpoint of full-year profit guidance exceeded current estimates. Burlington's shares rose Thursday but erased those gains Friday.Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) and video game vendor GameStop (GME) each reported April quarter results that beat views. But while Best Buy guided Wall Street higher for the current quarter, GameStop gave an in-line outlook. Best Buy stock soared to a record high, while GameStop sank below its 50-day moving average.The China-based social media and live-video streaming app on Tuesday reported adjusted first-quarter earnings that skyrocketed 630% vs. a year a year ago, with revenue rising 421% to $265.2 million. Those were well above estimates. But Momo (MOMO), which had reversed lower from a record high on Monday, kept falling, losing 10% as of Friday afternoon, though it did find support at its 50-day line.Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) galloped 14% to a record high stock price after delivering better-than-expected March-quarter results. Investors shrugged off the news that Take-Two is delaying its highly anticipated Wild West shooter game "Red Dead Redemption 2" to spring 2018 from this fall. The focus at Take-Two has shifted from big game releases to long-term recurring revenue from major game properties like "Grand Theft Auto Online" and "NBA 2K" through downloadable content and online services.Ford (F) dumped Mark Fields after the stock and earnings had fallen sharply, lagging peers. New CEO Jim Hackett, who had run Ford's autonomous driving unit, is seen as a turnaround specialist. Meanwhile, the Justice Department sued Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), accused it of cheating on emission tests on many diesel pickup trucks. General Motors faced a new private lawsuit for allegedly installed software 'defeat devices' for various diesels as well. The diesel emissions saga took off in 2015, when Volkswagen (VLKAY) came under scrutiny.Toll Bros. (TOL) topped fiscal second-quarter earnings estimates, helped by demand for "affordable" luxury homes. But shares of Toll and other builders retreated as U.S. new-home sales for April fell to a level well below expectations. Existing-home sales also sank more than expected. Home-improvement retailer Lowe's (LOW) Q1 results missed.Investors punished suppliers of automotive replacement parts for big earnings misses. AutoZone (AZO) gapped down 12% Tuesday to its lowest level in more than two years. Advance Auto Parts (AAP) sank nearly 5% Tuesday, then fell 5% Wednesday after its own miss. O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), which tumbled below its 50-day line after its April 27 earnings report, fell 1.1% for the week, well off weekly lows. Their weak results and stock performances come as Amazon (AMZN) reportedly mulls breaking into the auto parts market.Adjusted profit per share advanced 47% while revenue grew 32% to $157.9 million, both comfortably topping Wall Street estimates. The cloud-based software maker for the life sciences industry also gave guidance above the Wall Street consensus. Veeva (VEEV) shares jumped 8.2% to a new record high Friday.Dycom said its adjusted Q3 earnings were $1.30 a share, up 20% from a year earlier, with revenue rising 18% to $786.3 million for the period ended April 29. Both topped views. But the telecom installer forecast EPS in a range of $1.35 to $1.50 and revenue in a range of $789 million to $810 million vs. consensus estimates of $1.79 and $849.4 million. Dycom shares plunged more than 22% for the week.Upscale jeweler Tiffany (TIF) reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings Wednesday, but revenue fell short and same-store sales unexpectedly declined. Signet Jewelers (SIG), parent of mall-based Kay Jewelers, Zales, and Jared The Galleria of Jewelry, missed on earnings. Shares of both retailers tumbled.NetApp (NTAP) topped earnings and sales views, but gave weak guidance. Shares, which fell late Wednesday, rallied 3.5% in Thursday's regular session, retaking its 50-day line. But NetApp gave up some of those gains Friday.Splunk (SPLK) reported a smaller-than-expected Q1 adjusted per-share loss while revenue topped views, but shares fell 7% Friday, dropping back below a buy point. The data analytics firm gave in-line guidance.
