Even though Apple (AAPL) has shown no appetite for making large acquisitions, Wall Street analysts continue to speculate that the iPhone maker will use its massive cash stockpile to make a game-changing deal.Investment bank Citigroup is the latest to weigh in on what Apple might do with its war chest, which totaled $256.8 billion in cash and marketable securities as of April 1. Of that amount, 93% is outside the U.S.Citi analyst Jim Suva says internet television network Netflix (NFLX) is the most likely target for Apple if it decides to make a big acquisition. He puts 40% odds on a Netflix buyout, according to media reports citing the firm's note to clients Friday titled "Addressing the Problem of Too Much Cash."Any major deal would be contingent on U.S. corporate tax reform, specifically a better rate for repatriating foreign profits. Citi thinks a 10% repatriation tax on foreign cash would entice Apple to make a big M&A deal.Another possible acquisition target is entertainment conglomerate Walt Disney (DIS), Suva says. He puts the odds of Apple buying Disney at 25%.Other companies that Apple might have an interest in buying include luxury electric car maker Tesla (TSLA), streaming video service Hulu, and video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO). He put their odds of being acquired by Apple at 10% or less.IBD'S TAKE: Apple is on IBD's Leaderboard list of actionable stocks with the potential for big gains.A Netflix acquisition would make the most sense for Apple, Suva said."Netflix is global, has no noncore assets (like Disney) and is disrupting the global video ecosystem," Suva said. "Apple could help accelerate this disruption. That is, since Apple is very cash generative, it could help Netflix accelerate — and deepen — its push into original content."Netflix has a market capitalization of $67.5 billion. Apple's largest acquisition to date was its $3 billion purchase of headphone maker Beats Electronics and its fledgling streaming music service in 2014.In an interview with CNBC on Tuesday, Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook said his company wants to be a player in online video."The video world has kind of hit an air pocket," Cook said. "Where cord-cutting has been happening on some kind of basis, we think it's accelerating massively and that it's clear what the end story looks like here. The trajectory is a debate. But we'd like to play in this."To date, Apple's focus in the streaming video market has been on selling third-party services like Netflix, Hulu and Time Warner's (TWX) HBO through its App Store and taking a fee for managing payments. Recode reported Friday that Apple is nearing a deal to offer Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Prime Video service through its Apple TV set-top box, possibly by the third quarter.Apple also is funding some original video content for its Apple Music service. That content will include shows like "Carpool Karaoke."Apple stock rose 1.7% to 148.96 on the stock market today. In intraday trading, it hit a record high of 148.98.Netflix stock sank 0.4% to 156.60 after hitting a record 158.55 intraday.RELATED:Apple CEO Cook Discloses $1 Billion Advanced Manufacturing Fund5 Key Takeaways From Netflix's Landmark EarningsWill Video Kill The iPhone Star? Apple Lethargic On Streaming TV

GameStop (GME) shares tumbled to a one-month low Tuesday after Microsoft (MSFT) announced a new Netflix (NFLX)-like service that makes more than 100 online game titles available for a monthly fee. Consumer electronics giant Best Buy (BBY) also sold off.Microsoft announced Xbox Game Pass, where users can access the games for a monthly fee of $9.99. It's slated to arrive this spring. The available games are Xbox One and Xbox 360 titles from Microsoft, Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment and others.The Microsoft move is expected to cut into GameStop's lucrative retail video-game business, in which sales of pre-owned and older games account for about 25% of company revenue.GameStop stock tumbled 7.8% to finish at 24.44 in the stock market today, dropping below its 50-day moving average. Microsoft dipped 0.4% to 63.98.Best Buy is less exposed to video games, but shares tumbled 4.4%to sink below its 50-day moving average. Best Buy reports earnings before Wednesday's market open.IBD'S TAKE: Microsoft is showing a relatively weak IBD Composite Rating of 63, meaning it has outperformed 63% of stocks in the past six months based on a variety of metrics. GameStop has a Composite Rating of just 19. For a look at top-performing stocks, check out IBD'S Tech Leaders.GameStop has had a rough couple of years, hurt mainly by the shift to digital game downloads and away from packaged media.In response, GameStop has diversified its business from video games to mobile devices and pop-culture collectibles.In addition to GameStop stores, it also runs shops that sell AT&T (T) and Apple (AAPL) products.GameStop in mid-January reported that its same-store sales plummeted nearly 19% during the nine-week holiday period through December. Shares of the Grapevine, Texas-based company fell on that news. GameStop said its total sales for the holiday period fell 16.4% year over year to $2.5 billion.RELATED: Google Plays Catch-Up In The Cloud With Amazon And Microsoft

The video game industry hit a soft spot in May, with sales falling 13% year over year. The NPD Group reported late Thursday that U.S. retail sales of new video game products totaled $507.6 million last month, compared with $584.9 million in May 2014.
Sales of accessories, such as interactive gaming toys, game pads and headsets, rose 20% to $149.3 million. Nintendo's (NTDOY) Amiibo toys led the category.
But sales of video game hardware and software fell.

Game hardware sales dropped 18% to $153.6 million, because of lower prices for consoles. Unit sales of eighth-generation consoles, including Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, were stable in May, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.

Sales of video game software on physical media fell 25% to $204.7 million. Software sales faced poor comparisons to a strong release slate in May 2014, which included the launches of Nintendo's "Mario Kart 8" and Ubisoft's "Watch Dogs," Callahan said.
"Despite poor comparisons to May 2014 releases, eighth-generation consoles software unit sales rose 8% in May 2015," he said.
The No. 1 best-selling game last month was "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.

"With a consistent stream of launches through the first five month of 2015, Warner Bros. Interactive is the top software publisher year to date through May 2015, with over 140% increase in dollar sales vs. last year," Callahan said. "Warner is poised for further growth with the launch of highly-anticipated 'Batman: Arkham Knight,' in June."
The No. 2 game last month was Warner Bros.'s "Mortal Kombat X," which topped the charts in April.
Rounding out the top five were "Grand Theft Auto 5" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), "Minecraft" from Microsoft and "Splatoon" from Nintendo.

Video game retailer GameStop (GME) crushed Wall Street's Q1 estimates and ripped out its still-beating heart in triumph late Thursday, thanks to hit titles like ultra-violent fighting game "Mortal Kombat X."
GameStop stock jumped 6% to 43 in morning trading on the stock market today.

The Grapevine, Texas-based retailer earned 68 cents a share, up 15% year over year, on sales of $2.06 billion, up 3%, for the quarter ended May 2. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected GameStop to earn 59 cents a share on sales of $2.01 billion.
Same-store sales rose 8.6% in fiscal Q1, compared with 5.8% in the year-earlier period.
GameStop said its software sales were helped by hot games like "Mortal Kombat X" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment and "Battlefield Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA).
For the current quarter, GameStop expects to earn 23 cents a share, up 5%, based on the midpoint of its guidance, with same-store sales flat to up 3%.

For the full year, GameStop raised its EPS guidance range to $3.63 to $3.83 from its previously announced range of $3.60 to $3.80 to account for the reduction in shares outstanding. It still expects full-year comparable store sales to rise 1% to 6%.

GameStop operates more than 6,700 stores across 14 countries. In addition to GameStop stores, it runs Simply Mac stores, which sell Apple (AAPL) products, and Spring Mobile stores, which sell AT&T (T) wireless products and services.
GameStop's performance was helped by conservative guidance and stock buybacks, which lifted earnings per share, Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said in a research note Friday.

GameStop is facing "massive pessimism" with short interest at 47%, said Janney Capital Markets analyst Tony Wible. GameStop is the most shorted name in the S&P 500, he said in a note Friday. Critics say GameStop's physical game software sales are being undermined by growing digital downloads of full games.

Wible rates GameStop stock as a buy and raised his price target to 46 from 42. He is bullish on GameStop because of the console upgrade cycle and new business opportunities in selling Apple iDevices and digital game content.

GameStop is benefiting from a "renewed growth phase" in the video game industry, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday. This phase is being driven by the console upgrade cycle as more gamers switch to the latest living-room consoles such as Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One.
Olson rates GameStop stock as overweight with a price target of 47.

"While those negative on GME will point to digital disintermediation as the source of potential pre-owned weakness, we believe GameStop is strategically positioned to capture industrywide growth in new and pre-owned software & hardware," Olson said. "The footprint of next-gen consoles continues to outpace its predecessor, which we believe bodes well for accompanying software sales (new and pre-owned) in the coming quarters."
The console upgrade cycle also is boosting the fortunes of game publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).
Baird analyst Colin Sebastian believes GameStop's momentum will continue this year.

"While the company's long-term position remains under scrutiny given the inevitable shift of media consumption online, we believe the company should benefit from a high-quality lineup of core games coinciding with the next-generation console cycle, and positive comp store sales continuing through 2015," Sebastian said in a note Friday.
RELATED:
Did Osama bin Laden play a Delta Force video game?

Gaming software stocks were Tuesday's top-performing industry group, up solidly on the back of a stellar earnings report from Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), which gapped up on monster volume. The industry group is up more than 20% year to date and is ranked No. 4 out of 197 groups. Take-Two reported fiscal Q4 EPS of 49 cents a share, well ahead…
A better-than-expected report on April housing starts couldn't light a fire under investors Tuesday as the market finished narrowly mixed, unable to find direction .

The Nasdaq closed 0.2% lower; the S&P 500 lost 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.1% in the stock market today. Volume was higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq, according to preliminary statistics.

In after-hours trading, IPO Etsy (ETSY) dropped sharply. The art-and-crafts website reported a loss of 84 cents a share. Analysts were expecting a small profit. The stock came public April 16 with an offering price of 16 and traded as high as 35.74 on the first day. It closed Tuesday at 21.
Also after the close, shares of Yahoo (YHOO) were lower. The action was attributed to news China might impose an import tax on cross-border e-commerce.

Home Depot (HD) reversed and closed nearly 2% lower. It opened higher after reporting earnings that beat estimates. The company said its gardening tool sales were above average, and it expects to introduce more innovative outdoor tools this summer.

Gaming software was the best-performing industry group of the day with a 2.6% boost. It was led by Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), up 18% on monster volume after reporting fiscal Q4 earnings that topped estimates and issuing guidance above views. Take-Two has been lagging but is now above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages and may have begun building the right side of a base. Sterne Agee CRT upgraded the stock to buy from neutral.
Oil-related stocks were among the worst performers. Oil fell 3%. West Texas intermediate is now back below $60 a barrel.

After the market opens Wednesday, crude oil inventories will be reported for the week ended May 15 by the Energy Information Agency. Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), maker of the hit pro basketball video game "NBA 2K15," delivered a slam dunk Monday for its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings.Take-Two stock rose 18% to 28.62 on the stock market today. The game publisher, best known for its "Grand Theft Auto" series, hit a record high of 30.80 on Jan. 28.For the quarter ended March 31, Take-Two earned 49 cents a share excluding items, up 133% year over year and beating Wall Street's target of 27 cents. Sales rose 83% to $428 million, short of the $459 million expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Take-Two lost $2.99 a share in Q4, vs. a year-earlier profit of 40 cents a share. GAAP sales rose 54% to $300 million.The largest contributors to Take-Two's revenue growth in Q4 were "Grand Theft Auto 5," "Grand Theft Auto Online," "Evolve," "NBA 2K15" and "Borderlands: The Handsome Collection," the New York-based company said."Fiscal 2016 is off to a great start, highlighted by the April launch of 'Grand Theft Auto 5' for the PC, which has exceeded our expectations," Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said in a statement. "Throughout the coming year, we will continue to execute our proven strategy of launching a select array of the highest-quality titles, led by new annual releases of 'NBA 2K' and 'WWE 2K'; 'Battleborn,' a groundbreaking new intellectual property from Gearbox Software; and a soon-to-be announced new triple-A title from 2K."Price Target LoweredTake-Two had a "mixed quarter," but its outlook was "not as bad as feared," said Baird analyst Colin Sebastian in a research report Tuesday.Sebastian rates Take-Two stock as neutral and lowered his price target to 33 from 34.For its fiscal Q1, Take-Two expects to earn 30 cents a share on sales of $337.5 million. Analysts were expecting the company to lose 2 cents a share on sales of $207.2 million. Take-Two's guidance reflects continued strength in GTA 5, "Grand Theft Auto Online" and "NBA 2K15," Sebastian said.Its full-year guidance looks conservative, Sebastian said. Management expects fiscal 2016 sales and EPS to be $1.35 billion and 88 cents, respectively, well below consensus of $1.49 billion and $1.76.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said the soft full-year guidance reinforces the company's "underwhelming" game release slate.Take-Two's newest game property, "Evolve," was a disappointment in Q1, Pacific Crest analyst Evan Wilson said."At only 2.5 million units sell-in to date, it sold only half of our 5 million estimate and is one of the smallest selling AAA new (intellectual properties) of this generation," Wilson said. He rates Take-Two stock as sector weight.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Take-Two stock but cut his price target to 34 from 35.Meanwhile, two other major game publishers — Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronics Arts (EA) — are trading at or near recent highs. The video game sector in general is benefiting from the growing installed base of next-generation video game consoles and the rise of digital downloads including full games and add-on content.IBD's Computer Software - Gaming group ranks No. 4 out of 197 industry groups.Activision stock rose a fraction Tuesday to 25.48, just below its all-time high of 25.66 reached on Friday.Electronic Arts stock dipped 1% to 62.61, just below its 10-year high of 63.50 reached on Monday.RELATED:Blood and gore drive video game sales higher.

Shares of Activision Blizzard (ATVI) soared by nearly 19% Friday, a day after the video game publisher delivered fourth-quarter sales and earnings that beat Wall Street's expectations thanks to hot-selling games like "Overwatch."Activision shared finished trading at 47.23, a gain of 7.50, or 18.9% on the stock market today, earlier touching an all-time high of 47.64 and hitting a buy point of 45.65 out of a 16-week consolidation.Meanwhile, shares of rivals Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) also jumped Friday, with both hitting record highs and EA remaining in a buy zone.EA, which broke out at 82.72 last month, ended the day up 3.5% to 86.17, earlier peaking at 86.33. Take-Two, well extended from its last breakout, was up 3.3% to 57.88 after earlier rising as high as 58.14.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision earned 92 cents a share excluding items, up 11% year over year, on adjusted sales of $2.45 billion, up 16%, in Q4. Analysts were expecting 73 cents EPS and $2.36 billion in sales.Under generally accepted accounting principles, Activision earned 33 cents a share, up 57%, on sales of $2.01 billion, up 49%, in Q4.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 78, meaning it has outperformed 78% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Activision, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, Activision expects to earn 18 cents a share on sales of $1.05 billion. Analysts were modeling 31 cents EPS and $1.20 billion in sales. But Activision is known for giving conservative guidance."Our record performance in 2016 further strengthened our position as the world's leading standalone interactive entertainment company," Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said in a statement. "The launch of Blizzard's 'Overwatch' created a major new franchise, while King's mobile advertising tests are very promising as the basis for meaningful new revenue streams."We accelerated our efforts in e-sports and consumer products, enabling more ways to celebrate and connect to our communities."Sales of "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" were below expectations during the holiday quarter, but it was offset by "Overwatch" core game sales and in-game microtransactions, as well as "World of Warcraft," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report. He rates Activision stock as overweight with a price target of 51.Mizuho Securities analyst San Phan reiterated his buy rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 50 from 45.Macquarie Capital analyst Ben Schachter maintained his outperform rating on Activision and upped his price target to 48 from 46.Activision also announced a two-year stock repurchase plan totaling $1 billion and raised its cash dividend by 15% to 30 cents a share.Like peers EA, Take-Two and Ubisoft, Activision is benefiting from the shift from packaged media to higher-margin digital downloads and in-game purchases.RELATED:'Grand Theft Auto' Video Game Maker Slays Q3 TargetsElectronic Arts Q3 Beats Guidance; 'FIFA 17' Top Console Game

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) late Tuesday murdered Wall Street's fiscal third-quarter targets thanks to hot games like "Mafia 3" and the continued success of the "Grand Theft Auto" franchise, sending shares to an all-time high early Wednesday.The New York City-based company earned 99 cents a share excluding items, up 11% year over year, on adjusted sales of $745 million, up 53%, in the December quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Take-Two to earn 96 cents a share on sales of $706 million.For the current quarter, the company's fiscal Q4, Take-Two said it expects to earn 53 cents a share ex items on adjusted sales of $342 million, based on the midpoint of guidance. Analysts were modeling for 53 cents EPS and $291 million in sales for the March quarter.Take-Two stock jumped as much as 5.6% in early trading on the stock market today, hitting a record high of 56.71. But shares soon reversed, and Take-Two stock ended the day up just a penny, at 53.71. Take-Two broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 46.88 on Nov. 3.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software has an IBD Composite Rating of 71, meaning it has outperformed 71% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 4 out of 15 companies in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Take-Two lost 33 cents a share in the December quarter, compared with a year-earlier loss of 51 cents.The largest contributors to Take-Two's revenue growth last quarter were "Grand Theft Auto 5" and "Grand Theft Auto Online," "WWE 2K17," "NBA 2K17" and "Sid Meier's Civilization 6," the company said."Take-Two had a highly successful holiday quarter," Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said in a conference call with analysts. "Consumer demand for our new releases and catalog was strong throughout the period and players continue to engage significantly with our games after purchase.""Grand Theft Auto 5" and "Grand Theft Auto Online" continue to outperform expectations, he said. "GTA 5" has sold more than 75 million units since its launch in September 2013.Crime saga game "Mafia 3," released Oct. 7, has sold about 5 million units to date.Take-Two received at least seven price-target hikes from investment banks after reporting Q3 results. Firms raising their price targets on Take-Two stock included Baird, Benchmark, Cowen, Macquarie Capital, Mizuho Securities, Oppenheimer and Piper Jaffray.Take-Two is the second of three major U.S.-traded video game publishers to report holiday quarter results. Electronic Arts (EA) on Jan. 31 reported fiscal Q3 sales and earnings that beat expectations. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter results after the close on Thursday.RELATED:Video Game Publisher Activision Added To Wedbush 'Best Ideas List'

George Soros took stakes in Facebook (FB) and Dow component Goldman Sachs (GS) in the fourth quarter, while Appaloosa cut its stake in Apple (AAPL), and both followed Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BKRB) in appearing to find a bargain in airlines. Here's a look at how some big investors managed their portfolios in the last quarter of last year.Soros Fund Management bought 353,686 shares in Facebook and bulked up its stake in Alphabet (GOOGL) by nearly 60% to 20,200 shares, according to a regulatory filing out late Tuesday. Soros also increased his T-Mobile (TMUS) stake to 685,700 shares.Soros bought 62,100 shares in Goldman Sachs. Dan Loeb's Third Point last week disclosed that it had scooped up shares of Goldman, Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).Bank stocks have risen on greater expectations of lighter regulations, higher interest rates and greater volatility, which Goldman's trading desk could benefit from in particular.Soros also took a 40,000-share stake in Delta Air Lines (DAL), but dropped United Airlines (UAL).Shares of Apple ended regular trading up 0.4% to 135.51 on the stock market today, after hitting a record high yesterday. Facebook fell 0.3% to 133.44, while Goldman Sachs rose 0.4% to 250.54. Delta climbed 2.6% to 51.17, American rose 2.1% to 47.54, and United gained 2.7% to 75.75.IBD'S TAKE: Even as big investors flocked to the airlines last year, Cowen analysts last month said shares of airlines could be "due for a break" after taking off in Q4. Meanwhile, Soros dropped Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Herbalife (HLF), Harley Davidson (HOG), PepsiCo (PEP) and JCPenney (JCP). He also dissolved his stake in Nordstrom (JWN)Soros also offloaded his position in consumer-care products giant Procter & Gamble (PG), which got a lift Tuesday after activist investor Trian took a more than $3 billion stake in the company.Hedge fund Appaloosa Management increased its stake in Facebook by 47% to 2.2 million shares. The fund also upped its holdings in Qualcomm (QCOM) and more than doubled its stake in Southwest (LUV). Appaloosa also took a 160,000-share stake in United Airlines.The fund loaded up on the health sector, taking new stakes in companies like Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY), Centene (CNC), McKesson (MCK) and Pfizer (PFE). It also took a new stake in JCPenney.Appaloosa cut its position in Apple by 350,000 shares, slashed its stake in Yahoo (YHOO) and rid itself of Bank of America and General Motors (GM).Along with boosting its stake in Apple, David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital dissolved its stake in Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), U.S. Steel (X) and Michael Kors (KORS).Like Buffett, Greenlight also took a stake in Monsanto (MON).But the moves by Soros and Appaloosa into airlines are notable in that they could signal other big investors are following Buffett, who announced Q3 stakes in the sector last year.Buffett, after years of avoiding the airlines, has come around to the industry. Airlines last year showed more signs of discipline, and the wave of consolidation over the past several years has kept the major airlines relatively insulated from new competition."When we launched on the sector late last year, we found most investors generally in agreement that airlines represented deep value," Barclays analyst Brandon Oglenski wrote in a research note dated Tuesday."The biggest question remains: when will the market and, more importantly, large long-term investors begin to care? We think tonight's Berkshire Hathaway 13F will go a long way to attract sector interest."RELATED:Airline Stocks Tumble On Fears Capacity May Creep Back UpDelta, American, United Go Guns Blazing Into Battle Of The AtlanticJPMorgan Sets Fresh High, Goldman Hits Highest Since 2007 On Yellen

LAS VEGAS – Wearable fitness tracker maker Fitbit (FIT) is looking to get people exercising more using financial incentives and gameplay, Fitbit CEO James Park told IBD at CES 2017, the annual consumer electronics show.Fitbit has accomplished a lot by providing users of its devices with automated words of encouragement and vibrations for reaching activity goals, such as 10,000 daily steps. But now it is looking for ways to get people moving by providing tangible benefits.For instance, Fitbit is participating in a wellness program offered by UnitedHealth (UNH) that gives members up to $4 a day in rewards for meeting activity goals.Participants can earn up to $1,500 a year in Health Savings Account (HSA) or Health Reimbursement Account (HRA) credits. And employers can obtain premium savings based on participants' combined results.IBD'S TAKE: CES is the tech industry's biggest show by far in the U.S., providing a start-of-the-year way to gauge what's ahead on the tech front, and IBD, as always, was there with print and video coverage of CES 2017.Fitbit is offering a customized Fitbit Charge 2 wristband for UnitedHealthcare Motion program participants.The Motion program "is the first insurance company initiative … where people are being paid money for physical activity," Park said Friday. "That's a big step forward."The program marks a "pivotal moment in the health care insurance industry," Park said. "We anticipate that other insurers will look at the details of this partnership and announcement to figure out what their play is."In November, Fitbit announced a partnership with Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) involving its "NBA 2K17" basketball video game. Players who achieve 10,000 steps in a day tracked with their Fitbit device will receive a temporary attribute boost to their MyPlayer in "NBA 2K17," enhancing their character's performance in the game.Park said he hopes to see more Fitbit partnerships with game companies in the future.Providing incentives is a good way to prod people to be more active, Park said."Fitness and health a lot of times is really tedious for people and so there's a lot of different motivations – gamification is one, incentives are another, support of the community is a third," he said.Among the software updates Fitbit announced for its devices at CES is a Community feature. That feature allows users to share more activity accomplishments on Facebook (FB) and Instagram and connect with friends and groups for added support and inspiration.Fitbit stock was down 1.4% to close at 7.79 on the stock market today, and amid ever tougher competition it's been trading below 10 for two months.RELATED:Winners And Losers From CES 2017: Nvidia, Amazon, Apple, Qualcomm

Analysts weighed in on highflying banks Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC), downgraded Exxon Mobil (XOM), hiked the price target for Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) and started coverage on GrubHub (GRUB).Analysts offered another take on banks a day after Citigroup cut its rating on Goldman Sachs (GS) to sell on valuation. The group has been propelled by expectations for higher rates and a steeper yield curve, a less-stringent regulatory framework and corporate tax cuts as well as stronger economic growth and capital markets activity.UBS gave Citigroup a sell rating and 58 price target. Analysts split over Bank of America, with UBS giving it a neutral rating and 23 target, but Citigroup hiking its target for BofA to 26 from 19, keeping a buy rating.Bank of America reports earnings on Friday, while Citigroup will report next week.Citigroup closed 0.45% lower at 59.96, while Bank of America rose 0.6% to 23.07 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Read why super-regional banks may be even better positioned than the too-big-to-fail giants like Citigroup to benefit from less regulation and stronger growth expected under the Trump administration.Wells Fargo downgraded the oil and gas giant to market perform from outperform and lowered its price target range to 87-93 from 92-100. Analyst Roger Read cited the stock's valuation and his belief that the window for an acquisition has likely passed with the oil market having found a degree of stability.Exxon Mobil rose 1% to finish at 86.81.Credit Suisse started coverage on the food-delivery site with an outperform rating and 48 price target. Analyst Paul Bieber said the company is well-positioned for growth as this very large, fragmented market moves online.GrubHub climbed 0.9% to 37.17.Stifel raised its price target for the video game publisher to 59 from 52, keeping a buy rating. Analyst Drew Crum called Take-Two's upcoming "Red Dead Redemption 2" game "a reason to own the shares."Shares gained 0.6% to 51.11.RELATED:Investors Eye Busy Week Of Financial Earnings; KB Home Also DueTake-Two A Top Pick, Tesaro A Buy, Ritchie Bros. Downgraded4 Top IBD 50 Stocks Setting Up New Buy Points For 2017U.S. Oil Companies To Unleash Spending But Costs Will Rise Too

After stumbling with its poor-selling Wii U video game console, Nintendo (NTDOY) is hoping for a comeback with its upcoming Switch console.Nintendo late Thursday detailed pricing and availability for the device, which can function as a living-room console player or a portable gaming machine. The Nintendo Switch will cost $299.99 and be available March 3.Nintendo stock fell Friday on the news because the device is more expensive than expected. Many analysts expected the Switch to retail for $200 to $250. Also, some game industry pundits have cast doubt on its prospects.Nintendo's U.S. shares tumbled 6.3% to 25.85 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Nintendo stock ranks ninth out of 15 companies in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. The No. 1 company is Chinese online games company NetEase. For more information on NetEase, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Nintendo is a distant third to Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One in the current generation of video game consoles, but it is hoping for better luck this go-round. Nintendo sold 13 million Wii U consoles, compared with 53 million units so far for Sony's market-leading PS4 console.SuperData Research analyst Joost van Dreunen told GamesIndustry.biz that he questions whether the Nintendo Switch will have broad appeal."I have my reservations with regards to the breadth of the audience it targets," he said. "The Switch will likely be most popular among a younger audience: Its functionality is uniquely geared toward pre-teens and teenagers."The Switch can convert from a living room system into a mobile game device. It features controllers that snap to the sides of a 6.2-inch tablet display in one gameplay mode and can be removed and played wirelessly in another mode. People also can use traditional batwing-style controllers with the console.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) is providing a custom Tegra processor for the Nintendo Switch.Nintendo announced several major first-party titles for the Switch, including "The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild," "Super Mario Odyssey," "Mario Kart 8 Deluxe" and "Splatoon 2."It said third-party game publishers such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA), Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and Ubisoft will support the new console.RELATED:Nintendo Unveils Versatile Video Game Console: Nintendo Switch
Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.

The video game industry returned to growth in April, fueled by violent action games led by "Mortal Kombat X."
The top three best-selling games at U.S. retail last month were rated M for Mature, with content considered suitable for players ages 17 and up.
"Mortal Kombat X" from Time Warner (TWX) unit Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment was the No. 1 game in April. It's the latest in the long-running fight-to-the-death game series.

"Mortal Kombat X" features "blood and gore, intense violence and strong language," according to the Entertainment Software Rating Board. It's available for Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Windows PCs.

"After an opponent is defeated at the end of a match, players perform finishing moves called 'Fatalities' that can result in characters' impalement, dismemberment, or decapitation," ESRB said. "Many of these finishing moves depict over-the-top instances of violence: a character ripped in half; a character's face sliced off with a sword; a character mauled in half, leaving entrails exposed."

"Grand Theft Auto 5," the current chapter in the popular crime saga from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), came in second place. Take-Two had three games in the top 10 last month, with the others being "NBA 2K15" and "Borderlands: The Handsome Collection."
GTA 5 features "blood and gore, intense violence, mature humor, nudity, strong language, strong sexual content and use of drugs and alcohol," ESRB said.

"Battlefield Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA) was the third best-selling game in April, after being No. 1 in March. It features "blood and gore, intense violence, strong language and use of drugs," ESRB said.

Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail rose 3% year over year to $596 million in April, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. Game sales fell 6% in March, after being up 8% in February and down 5% in January, NPD said.
Physical sales of new game software rose 13% to $257 million, boosted by a growing installed base of next-generation consoles including the PS4, Xbox One and Nintendo's (NTDOY) Wii U.
In April, game hardware sales dropped 4% to $184 million and accessories sales dipped 3% to $155 million, NPD said.
The video game software sector ranks No. 6 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. That's up from No. 8 a week ago, No. 28 four weeks ago and No. 55 eight weeks ago.
Top publicly traded video game publishers have been surging thanks to the console upgrade cycle.
Electronic Arts stock is just below a 10-year high of 63.46 reached Monday, down a fraction in afternoon trading Friday.
Activision Blizzard (ATVI) hit a record high intraday Friday of 25.66 and was up more than 1% in afternoon trading.
RELATED:
Activision Q1 report calm before the 'Storm'

E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends This year's Electronic Entertainment Expo, better known as E3, comes at an auspicious time for the video game industry. Leading publicly traded game companies have seen their stocks rally as the console upgrade cycle hits its sweet spot. Top publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) have helped…

Cops-and-robbers video game "Battlefield Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA) shot up the competition last month in what was an overall down month for the video game sector."Battlefield Hardline" was the No. 1 best-selling video game at U.S. retail in March, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. Sony's (SNE) "Bloodborne" came in second place for sales, followed by Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) "Grand Theft Auto 5" and Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Mario Party 10."Overall sales of new video game products fell 6% year over year to $964 million in March, NPD said. Game hardware suffered the biggest drop, down 21% to $311 million. Game software sales dipped 3% to $395 million. Game accessory sales rose 15% to $257 million.In February, total new video game product sales rose 8% following four straight months of decline, NPD said.Declining sales of new consoles, such as Microsoft 's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony's PlayStation 4, were behind the drop in hardware last month."Console hardware was the primary culprit responsible for the March 2015 sales decline, with a 29%, or $104 million decrease, in spending while portable hardware rose by 71% over last year," NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.Accessory sales were boosted by video game point and subscription cards, gamepads, and interactive gaming toys.RELATED:New 'Guitar Hero' game rocks Activision stock.

After declining four straight months, sales of new video game products at U.S. retail returned to growth in February. Sales of video game hardware, software and accessories rose 8% year over year to $956 million last month, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. The industry segment was helped by strong sales of the latest generation living-room consoles from Microsoft (MSFT) and Sony (SNE).Portable game players from Nintendo (NTDOY) also gave a boost.Game hardware sales rose 10% to $378 million. Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's PlayStation 4 saw sustained momentum in February. After 15 months on the market, Xbox One and PS4 have outsold their predecessors, the Xbox 360 and PS3, by close to 60% in terms of units, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.Nintendo's 3DS handheld device got a boost from the release of "The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask 3D," an exclusive first-party title. It was the top-selling game software title in February.Sales of new packaged game software rose 7% to $339 million last month. After the Zelda game, the top-selling titles were science-fiction game "Evolve" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and zombie horror game "Dying Light" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment."Dying Light" was the top-selling game in January.Game accessory sales rose 8% to $239 million in February thanks to continued growth of video game point and subscription cards and interactive gaming toys.The NPD figures do not include sales of used game products, rentals or digital sales, such as game downloads and subscriptions.The uptick in sales for the U.S. retail video game segment is likely to be short-lived.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz predicts that March sales will fall by about 15% year over year because of a dearth of new releases. March 2014 saw the release of "Titanfall," "Infamous: Second Son," "Dark Souls II" and "South Park: The Stick of Truth," whereas the only new major AAA title this March is "Battlefield: Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA), he said.RELATED:Game over for Xbox One; PS4 seen winning by big marginKing Digital continues to 'crush' mobile game competitionIn-App Purchases Fueling Mobile Game Sales.

Zombie apocalypse video game "Dying Light" is a hit title, but it wasn't enough to prevent overall sales of video game products from falling for the fourth straight month at U.S. retail in January.Created by Polish video game developer Techland and distributed by Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, "Dying Light" was the No. 1 best-selling console video game last month, the NPD Group reported late Thursday.Video game hardware, software and accessories sales at U.S. retail fell 5% year over year in January to $626 million, NPD said. The NPD figures do not include sales of used game products, rentals or digital sales, such as game downloads and subscriptions.Video game software sales at U.S. retail rose 6% year over year in January to $236 million."Upside was entirely driven by Warner Bros.' release 'Dying Light,'" Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a note Friday. "Warner Bros.' zombie-slayer more than doubled our estimate despite being at retail for just five days. We suspect the game will sell through around 1 million units, including digital, in the U.S. by the end of March."The best selling game for December and all of 2014, Activision's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare," came in second place for January.Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) crime saga "Grand Theft Auto 5" was the No. 3 selling game in January, followed by Microsoft's (MSFT) "Minecraft" and Take-Two's "NBA 2K15."Game hardware sales fell 23% to $186 million last month, as demand cooled after the holiday season. Sales of eighth-generation consoles, including Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, continue to outpace the prior generation, NPD said."The combined hardware installed base of PS4 and Xbox One is close to 60% higher than the cumulative hardware totals for Xbox 360 and PS3 at the same point in their lifecycles (after 15 months)," NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.Sales of game accessories rose 3% year over year to $205 million last month, fueled by demand for gamepads, interactive gaming toys, headsets, headphones and power supplies.Big games out in February and March include Take-Two's "Evolve," which was released on Tuesday, and Electronic Arts ' (EA) "Battlefield: Hardline," set for release March 17.RELATED:'Call of Duty' maker combating foreign currency woes'Grand Theft Auto' maker slays holiday quarter targetsEA soars to 7-year high on holiday game sales.

Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) didn't get a big bounce from December-quarter earnings like its peers Electronic Arts and Take-Two Interactive Software. But it did experience a change in sentiment to the positive in trading Friday.Activision stock was down as much as 7% from Thursday's close in morning trading Friday. But by midday it was up more than 1% to a more than four-month high. By midafternoon trading on the stock market today, however, Activision stock was down a fraction, below 22.Late Thursday, Activision reported Q4 earnings that beat expectations, but sales in the holiday quarter came up short. The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company earned 94 cents a share excluding items, up 19% year over year, on sales of $2.21 billion, down 3%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 88 cents and $2.24 billion."2014 was another successful year as we achieved record results and introduced new franchises with outstanding gameplay, expanded on exciting new business models and continued investing in some of the world's most important entertainment franchises," Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said in a statement. "We expanded our franchise portfolio by launching two of the industry's most successful new brands, Blizzard's 'Hearthstone: Heroes of Warcraft,' and the biggest new IP launch in industry history, 'Destiny.'"Activision boasted three of the top five best-selling games of 2014: "Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare," "Destiny" and "Skylanders Trap Team."But Activision forecast declining sales and earnings for the current quarter and year. It blamed foreign currency exchange issues. About half of its sales and a higher percentage of profits are generated outside the U.S., Activision said.For the March quarter, Activision expects to earn 5 cents a share ex items, down 74%, on sales of $640 million, down 17%.For the year, Activision is targeting EPS of $1.15, down 19%, on sales of $4.4 billion, down 9%.To soften the blow, Activision raised its cash dividend by 15% to 23 cents a share and authorized a two-year stock repurchase plan of $750 million and a debt paydown of $250 million."Looking into 2015, we expect Activision to feel the effects of the strengthening U.S. dollar weighing on revenues and EPS," BMO Capital Markets analyst Edward Williams said in a research note Friday. "Activision's product development studios are principally in the U.S., preventing the company from offsetting the revenue headwinds with lower operating expenses."Williams reiterated his outperform rating Activision stock but lowered his price target to 25 from 27.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson says Activision is being conservative with its guidance."Activision management has historically underpromised and overdelivered," he said in a report Friday. "The company has exceeded its original revenue and EPS guidance on average by 8% and 20% between 2009 and 2014."Olson rates Activision stock as overweight with a price target of 25.Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), publisher of the "Grand Theft Auto" game series, rose to an all-time high after it reported better-than-expected December-quarter earnings on Tuesday.Last week, Electronic Arts (EA) soared to a seven-year high on strong console game sales during the holiday season.Electronics Arts stock was down more than 1% in afternoon trading Friday, while Take-Two stock was down a fraction.

Mizuho Securities named gaming software maker Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) a top pick for 2017, FBR Capital Markets upgraded cancer drug developer Tesaro (TSRO) to outperform, and Raymond James downgraded Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers (RBA) to neutral.Take-Two's "Red Dead Redemption" looks like a hot title heading into next year, says Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi, who named the game maker his top stock pick with a price target of 52.Take Two stock closed 0.3% lower at 49.73 in the stock market today.Take-Two stock has climbed 43% in 2016 and is still in a buy range at 46.88. Mizuho maintains a buy rating on Electronic Arts (EA). China-based NetEase (NTES), the No. 1 rated stock in IBD's Computer-Software Gaming group, on Monday announced the launch of 12 new game titles in 2017 including eight mobile games. Jefferies maintains a buy rating and price target of 261, citing NetEase's expansion into augmented reality.EA rose 0.5% while NetEase edged up 0.1%.FBR upgraded Tesaro to outperform and raised its price target to 151 from 133. Tesaro stock jumped last week after the Food and Drug Administration granted priority review for its ovarian cancer medication.Shares in Waltham, Mass.-based Tesaro fell 2.3% to 136.66.Tesaro stock has leapt 87% in 2016, though the stock has slipped from a record high of 148.74 on Nov. 14. Tesaro stock has been consolidating and has a buy point of 140.65. IBD's Medical-Biomed group is ranked No. 50 out of 197 industry groups. Supernus Pharmaceuticals (SUPN) is the group's top-rated stock.Raymond James downgraded Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers to market perform from buy. Ritchie Bros. specializes in auctioning heavy equipment used in farming, energy and transportation.Ritchie Bros. stock fell 5.6% to 34.02. Shares had been up about 50% in 2016. They are still near a buy point of 37.33.In other analyst moves, H.C. Wainwright raised its price target on Akebia Therapeutics (AKBA) to 18 from 17. Akebia last week announced that it has entered into a U.S. licensing agreement with Japan-based Otsuka Pharmaceutical for a drug treating chronic kidney disease.RELATED:Tesaro Ovarian Cancer Drug Gets Priority Review After FDA OKs Clovis MedTake-Two Interactive Software Poised To Gain From 'Red Dead' Game

The Nasdaq composite soared to an all-time high early Monday, helped in part by strength in Tesla (TSLA) and Apple (AAPL).The Nasdaq jumped 0.8%, while gains were more subdued in the NYSE indexes. The S&P 500 added 0.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.2%. Volume in the early going was tracking higher than Friday's light levels, more so on the Nasdaq.The Dow has been trying to crack the 20,000 level in recent days to no avail. For now, it's a resistance level for the blue-chip index. The 5500 level had been resistance for the Nasdaq but not anymore. It traded at 5512 less than one hour into the session.Shares of Tesla jumped 3%, while Apple rose 1% to 117.68. Apple is closing on quickly on a breakout over a 118.79 buy point, but Tesla has a long recovery ahead.In the stock market today, Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) added 1% after Mizuho Securities named the gaming software maker a top pick for 2017. Take-Two is extended after a breakout in early November and bounce off the 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, a couple of biotechs made early headlines. Ionis Pharmaceuticals (IONS) gapped up and rose 3%. Late Friday, the company said the Food and Drug Administration approved its spinal muscular atrophy treatment, Spinraza. Biogen (BIIB) has the global rights to develop and commercialize the drug, and its shares rose 3%.On the downside, Seattle Genetics (SGEN) plunged 13% after the FDA placed holds on several early-stage trials of its drug to treat acute myeloid leukemia.Meanwhile, Leaderboard name Veeva Systems (VEEV) gained 1% to 41.96. After a pullback, it's testing support at its 50-day moving average and is just below a prior 42.68 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: Veeva CEO Peter Gassner talks about business prospects and catalysts for the cloud software firm in 2017.Nvidia (NVDA), BofI Holding (BOFI), and MaxLinear (MXL) were top gainers in the IBD 50, with gains of around 3%.RELATED:Take-Two A Top Pick, Tesaro A Buy, Ritchie Bros. Downgraded

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) has a bright outlook for 2017, especially with the release of western action game "Red Dead Redemption 2," investment bank Cowen said Monday.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz reiterated his outperform rating on Take-Two stock and raised his price target to 58 from 54. He also elevated the stock to "best idea" status for 2017."Fundamentals for the video game space remain strong and TTWO has the best catalyst path into 2017," Creutz said in his research report.Take-Two stock rose 0.5% to 50.03 on the stock market today, nearly 9% extended from a breakout at 45.97 touched on Nov. 3. Take-Two hit an all-time high of 50.56 on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 62, meaning it has outperformed 62% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. It ranks No. 3 out of 15 stocks in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which stocks lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."We believe that with fiscal 2017 results largely derisked due to the strong performances of 'NBA 2K17' and 'Mafia 3,' the case for owning the stock ahead of what we expect to be a very successful 'Red Dead Redemption 2' launch in fall 2017, and a significant uptick in fiscal 2018 EPS, is very straightforward," Creutz said. "On average earnings power, Take-Two continues to trade at a discount to peers."Take-Two's fiscal 2017 ends March 31.Take-Two historically has traded at a discount to rivals Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) because of its volatile product release schedule tied to big games.But with the success of the "NBA 2K" and WWE series games as well as "Grand Theft Auto Online" that has become less of a factor, Creutz said.RELATED:Activision Shot Down By 'Call Of Duty' Sales ConcernsRetailers Heavily Discount Video Games To Drive SalesHoliday Video game Gifts: Wrapped Present Or Digital Download?

The kickoff to the holiday shopping season was marked by steep discounts on top-end, or AAA, video-game titles as retailers sought to drive consumer traffic into their stores."We saw greater discounting of high-profile new video games this Black Friday compared to last year," Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said in a research report Monday.Games that usually maintain their list prices were discounted 40% or more this Black Friday weekend, he said.For instance, Wal-Mart (WMT) was selling "Battlefield 1" and "Titanfall 2" from Electronic Arts (EA) for $27 each and Microsoft's (MSFT) "Gears of War 4" and Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) "Mafia 3" for $35 each. Wal-Mart also offered Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare, Legacy Edition" for $57, a $23 discount. Standard editions of those games have a list price of $59.99.During Black Friday last year, top-flight games like Activision Blizzard's "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," Bethesda Softworks' "Fallout 4" and EA's "Star Wars Battlefront" maintained their list prices, at $60 each.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two Interactive Software, Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts are ranked third, fourth and fifth, respectively, in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, game hardware discounts for Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 consoles was similar to those seen a year ago, Pachter said.A plethora of big game software and new game consoles has given consumers pause, he said."A combination of desirable new hardware and new software all hitting the market largely within a month appears to have caused hesitation among consumers about how to allocate their spending, with that hesitation increasing further following the emergence of compelling Black Friday ads earlier this month," Pachter said.New midcycle consoles include Microsoft's Xbox One S and Sony's PlayStation 4 Pro and PS4 Slim.Many of the game discounts were likely retail "loss leaders," designed to get shoppers into stores, Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a report Monday.The only new games not seeing big discounts were "Pokemon Sun" and "Pokemon Moon" from Nintendo (NTDOY), he said.Game software sales have become more difficult for analysts to track lately since a growing percentage are digital downloads direct from the publishers.Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey on Monday reiterated his sell rating on GameStop (GME) stock and lowered his price target to 20.11 from 20.67. He believes the retailer will be hit hard by the shift to digital downloads.Hickey said he is "largely unimpressed" by GameStop's diversification strategy, moving more into sales of mobile phones and pop-culture collectibles.Shares of Take-Two and EA were both down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, while Activision stock was up a fraction. GameStop stock, though, finished the trading day down 2.6% to 25.15 and facing a test at its 50-day line.RELATED:GameStop Jumps On Q3 Earnings Beat, Diversification StrategyHoliday Video-Game Gifts: Wrapped Present Or Digital Download?

The video-game industry is at a crossroads this holiday season as consumers must decide in what form they want to purchase new game software.Will they buy packaged game software so their kids will have something to open on Christmas morning? Or will they buy game software as digital downloads?How consumers respond will impact the top and bottom lines for game publishers and retailers.The biggest game publishers such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) lately have been benefiting from the move to digital downloads, which carry fatter profit margins.IBD'S TAKE: IBD Swing Trader uses CAN SLIM technical and fundamental research to find potential hits, not home runs. The goal is 10% profit within five to 10 days, with losses cut at 3%. Take-Two has been a Swing Trader stock of late.Retailers like GameStop (GME) and Best Buy (BBY) have been hurt by the shift to digital game distribution. But they might be able to compensate for that this holiday season thanks to the availability of new midcycle game consoles and the launch of virtual-reality headsets."Nothing is better under the Christmas tree than a box to open that has an actual gift," NPD analyst Mat Piscatella told IBD.Piscatella said he's seen no data yet to indicate that digital game download rates will be higher this holiday season. Video-game publishers have said top titles can sell 30% of units as digital downloads now. But what percentage is gifted is not known, Piscatella said.Many of those downloads probably are purchased by adult gamers who just want to play a new game right away, without having to get a physical game disc, he said.But game downloads have some disadvantages, such as having to wait for a huge digital file to download and install."You get it on Christmas Day and hopefully you're playing by New Year's," joked DFC Intelligence analyst David Cole.Publishers are offering special editions of games with collectibles and other extras to entice gamers to buy physical copies.At the same time, publishers are incentivizing gamers to get digital downloads by bundling in online season passes and pre-release game play.GameStop has been a canary in the coal mine for changes in the industry. On Tuesday, it reported disappointing fiscal third-quarter sales due in part to the increase in game software downloads.GameStop said new game titles sold below expectations for its fiscal Q3 ended Oct. 29. Analysts say Activision's "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" was among the games that came up short in physical game sales at GameStop last quarter.On the plus side, GameStop said the Nov. 18 release of Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Pokemon Sun and Moon" was the retailer's biggest game launch of the year. Nintendo games tend to have a lower digital download rate than those from other publishers. Nintendo customers tend to be younger.Other major game releases this fall include "Battlefield 1" and "Titanfall 2" from Electronic Arts and "Mafia 3" from Take-Two Interactive Software.Annual sports titles are likely to be big sellers this holiday season, including EA's "Madden NFL 17" and "FIFA 17" and Take-Two's "NBA 2K17" and "WWE 2K17."Other games looking to rack up big sales this Christmas include "Watch Dogs 2" from Ubisoft, "Dishonored 2" from Bethesda Softworks, and "Final Fantasy 15" from Square Enix.Publishers are cashing in on the sweet spot of the current game console cycle, where there's a large installed base of consoles in which to sell big game titles.Sony (SNE) is expected to have an installed base of 50 million PlayStation 4 consoles worldwide by year's end, DFC Intelligence said. Rival Microsoft (MSFT) is seen having 28 million Xbox One consoles in use by the end of 2016, DFC said.Game hardware revenue has been in decline this year because of market saturation and lower prices for consoles. Sony and Microsoft are hoping to change that with the recent launch of redesigned and souped-up versions of current consoles. Microsoft has the Xbox One S and Sony has the PlayStation 4 Pro and PS4 Slim. Plus, Nintendo has a retro console in its NES Classic Edition, which comes preinstalled with 30 games.Next year will bring two next-generation consoles: the Nintendo Switch and Microsoft Scorpio.This is the first Christmas season for virtual-reality headsets, including the games-focused Sony PlayStation VR. Other VR headsets include Facebook's (FB) Oculus Rift and HTC's Vive. Plus, there are low-cost VR headsets that use smartphone screens as their display, such as the Samsung Gear VR.Among the big VR games already out are "Batman: Arkham VR" from Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), and "NBA 2KVR Experience" from Take-Two. Electronic Arts is releasing its "Star Wars Battlefront Rogue One: X-Wing VR Mission" on Dec. 6."PS VR launch bundles being sold out pretty much everywhere is a positive sign" for adoption of virtual reality, Piscatella said. "There's a lot of excitement around (gaming) hardware and accessories this holiday."But this could be just a get-to-know-you period for VR. Best Buy, GameStop and others are offering demonstrations of VR systems in their stores to acquaint shoppers with the technology."Consumers haven't really been introduced to it yet," Cole told IBD. "2017 is the year that VR really gets started."Best Buy rolled out virtual-reality products to all of its stores during its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 29, and it has dedicated virtual-reality departments in more than 700 stores, CEO Hubert Joly told analysts on a conference call Nov. 17.Best Buy has given more than 300,000 virtual-reality demonstrations to customers so far, Joly said.And GameStop Chief Operating Officer Tony Bartel said the new gaming hardware products are "bright spots" for GameStop."We're seeing strong demand for new consoles, the PS4 Pro is off to a strong start and VR is generally on the shelves for less than 10 days," he said on a conference call with analysts. "We're also seeing solid consumer interest for the upcoming launch of Switch from Nintendo."The Switch uses physical media and Nintendo products have historically had a low digital download rate, so we expect this to be a console that drives strong sales of physical product along with the console."Activision stock fell a fraction to 37.22 in the stock market today, a half-day session that ended at 1 p.m. ET. Shares touched an all-time high of 45.55 on Oct. 25, but also hit a four-month low of 36.32 on Wednesday.EA stock also fell a fraction Friday, to 79.17. It's forming a flat base with a possible buy point of 86.17. Take-Two stock rose 0.68% to 48.81, in buy range after hitting a 46.88 buy point on Nov. 3 out of a flat base, and touching a record high of 50.19 on Nov. 7.GameStop shares fell nearly 1% Friday, while Best Buy stock fell 0.8% to 46.58. Best Buy touched a six-year-plus high of 47.29, buoyed by its earnings beat on Nov. 17.RELATED:Wireless Headphones, 4K TVs, Drones Top Christmas Wish ListsRoomba Maker iRobot Hopes To Clean Up This ChristmasBest Buy Posts Q3 Earnings Surprise, Sparked By iPhone 7, 4K TVs

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) earned a cautious upgrade from Pacific Crest Securities on Wednesday based on its low valuation.Pacific Crest analyst Brad Erickson raised his rating on Fitbit to sector weight, or neutral, from underweight, or sell. He continues to view fair value for Fitbit stock around 8. Fitbit fell 1% to 9.46 on the stock market today."While our views of maturity for wearables driving headwinds to growth remain, the stock now more fully reflects the skepticism we expressed in our Sept. 29 downgrade to underweight," Erickson said in his research report. "Fitbit faces increasingly stiffening headwinds to growth, driven by a lack of utility and poor user trends."IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has a lowly IBD Composite Rating of 9, meaning it has been outperformed by 91% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a list of better investment opportunities, check out the IBD 50 list of superior stocks.For Fitbit to regain its footing, it will need to show continued consumer demand for its devices and traction for corporate health care initiatives, Erickson said.He expects Fitbit unit sales growth to decelerate to the high single-digits in 2016 and then decline by 6.7% in 2017."We think fitness trackers are hitting saturation in developed markets, with opportunities in emerging geographies appearing much more limited, at least for Fitbit-like price points," Erickson said.Fitbit needs to compete more with Garmin (GRMN) and others in the sports watch category, Erickson said."The main opportunity where Fitbit could improve meaningfully in 2017 is in running watches," he said. "Fitbit needs to crack into the specialty channel, not to necessarily drive volume, but to drive consumer street credit as more than a tracker."Fitbit shares tumbled after the San Francisco-based company on Nov. 2 posted disappointing third-quarter results and badly missed Wall Street's targets for the December quarter.On Wednesday, video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) announced that it has partnered with Fitbit to give players of "NBA 2K17" in-game rewards for healthy activity tracked by Fitbit devices.Players who achieve 10,000 steps in a day tracked with their Fitbit device will receive a temporary attribute boost to their MyPlayer in "NBA 2K17," enhancing their in-game performance on the court.It's not the first tie-up between a wearables maker and a video game company.In September, Apple (AAPL) announced that it would bring "Pokemon Go" to the Apple Watch. The popular augmented reality game from Niantic has encouraged players to be more active by going for walks to look for and hatch digital creatures in the game.RELATED:Wireless Headphones, 4K TVs, Drones Top Christmas Wish ListsTake-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 Earnings

Here is your Investing Action Plan for Friday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day.JCPenney (JCP) reports third-quarter results, following results from Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN) on Thursday. Weekly rig-count data is due out from Baker Hughes (BHI).Meanwhile, several top stocks are trying to break out or hold buy points amid significant sector rotation following Tuesday's presidential election.Microsoft (MSFT) closed down 2.4% at 58.70 dipping below buy range from a 58.80 flat-base entry in August but still performing better than some of the other big tech players. Microsoft fell as low as 57.63 intraday Thursday, below its pivot point and its 50-day moving average.Papa John's (PZZA) fell 0.6% to 81.27 as its morning breakout attempt met resistance. Shares hit 83.10 intraday, briefly clearing an 82.64 buy point of a flat base begun in September.Data-security software provider Proofpoint (PFPT) also is trying to break out. It rose to 82.96 early then reversed to end down 0.7% at 79.01.Proofpoint has formed a cup-with-handle base with a 79.88 buy point.Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) gapped 4.2% lower to 46.97, still just above a 46.88 buy point. The stock broke out last week following the video-game developer's earnings report.Analysts expect the department-store giant to post a per-share loss of 21 cents, an improvement from the 47-cent per-share loss seen a year ago. Overall sales are seen rising 2% to $2.951 billion.Shares bolted 5.4% higher in the stock market today, but found resistance intraday at their 50-day and 200-day averages. Those key support lines crisscrossed over the past year and did so again this week.JCPenney's results will come as shopping-mall mainstays like Sears (SHLD) and Macy's close stores and cut jobs amid a migration to e-commerce. JCPenney hasn't been immune to that trend, but it has tried to put more effort toward better customer service and new items on its shelves as its rivals struggle.Before Thursday's market open, Macy's reported weaker-than-expected earnings while Kohl's topped views. After the market close, Nordstrom reported a surprise increase in quarterly earnings and sales that also topped views, while lifting its earnings outlook above consensus as well.Shares surged 6.5% late and pushed Macy's, Kohl's and JCPenney higher after hours too.Baker Hughes will report weekly U.S. rig count data. More rigs have come back online in recent months as oil prices have rebounded from longtime lows earlier this year. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) stock tumbled to a two-month low Friday after the video game publisher gave a holiday sales forecast that undershot Wall Street's expectations.Activision shares fell as much as 5.8% in early trading on the stock market today, and closed down 3.85% to 41.70. Activision stock hit a record high of 45.55 on Oct. 25.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision late Thursday reported third-quarter results that beat estimates. It earned 52 cents a share excluding items, topping the consensus estimate of 42 cents. Sales rose 57% to $1.63 billion, above analyst estimates for $1.57 billion.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Activision earned 26 cents a share in Q3, up 53% and beating the estimate of 11 cents EPS.For the December quarter, Activision forecast non-GAAP earnings per share of 74 cents on sales of $2.38 billion. Wall Street was modeling 80 cents and $2.48 billion.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. It ranks No. 15 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.Video game companies Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) this week both raised their Q4 guidance, though EA's outlook still came in a tad below Wall Street expectations. They both also posted Q3 beats, and their shares popped on the news.Analysts have been expecting a big holiday season for Activision, led by futuristic combat game "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," which was released Friday.Activision's below-the-Street guidance "is likely due to the company factoring in a healthy layer of conservatism around 'Call of Duty'," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a research report. "Activision management has historically under-promised and over-delivered, exceeding its original EPS guidance on average by 19% in the past 7 years."Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Activision stock with a price target of 51.Activision could see "meaningful upside to estimates as management pursues large new opportunities in e-sports, in-game advertising, and micro-transactions," Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald said in a report. "Advertising is a potential billion-dollar business and is not included in Street estimates."Fitzgerald rates Activision stock a buy with a price target of 55.At least three brokerages raised their price targets on Activision stock after its Q3 beat: Baird, Cowen and Wedbush.Activision's Q3 results were driven by its deep portfolio of game franchises, which include "World of Warcraft," "Overwatch," and "Call of Duty," Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in a report.Sebastian upped his price target on Activision to 50 from 46 and maintained his outperform rating.Take-Two shares rose 1 cent to 48.30 Friday while EA dipped 0.4% to 80.22.RELATED:Take-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 EarningsElectronic Arts Stock Gets Price-Target Hikes On Upbeat Q2 Report

Console video game players by a wide margin still favor buying games on physical discs as opposed to digital downloads, a new survey shows. That's good news for retailer GameStop (GME), which has been dogged by speculation that digital delivery of full console games will crush its business.

A Piper Jaffray survey of 608 people who own next-generation consoles found that 75% preferred buying physical discs that can be traded vs. buying a digital copy. The survey also determined that 44% of next-gen console owners have never purchased downloadable content.
The survey results suggest that the recent growth of digital downloads is likely to stall.

"Publishers have suggested that 10-20% of certain titles have been purchased as full game downloads," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday. "Early buyers of next-gen consoles (core gamers) should arguably be the group that is most apt to purchase full game downloads and given 75% of what should be a 'digital heavy' group prefers buying on physical disc, we don't anticipate a material near-term (next 4-6 quarters) change in mix toward full game downloads."

The transition to digital delivery and content is still nascent, which is a positive for GameStop, Olson said. GameStop is the nation's top video game retailer and does a big business in used games and trade-ins.
He rates GameStop stock as overweight with a price target of 51. GameStop was down a fraction, near 41, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.

Of the 608 people who own next-gen consoles, specifically Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony 's (SNE) PlayStation 4, 31% said that they were "most excited" about buying the next edition of Activision 's (ATVI) "Call of Duty" this year.
"Call of Duty" far outpaced the next most commonly cited games, Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) "NBA 2K16" at 17% and Microsoft's "Halo" at 14%.
The new Star Wars game from Electronic Arts (EA), "Star Wars: Battlefront," finished in fourth place at 13%, slightly ahead of Ubisoft's "Assassin's Creed."

"The Assassin's Creed franchise has historically sold in about 10 million units per year upon its annual release," Olson said. "We believe Star Wars' position, between two stalwart, proven franchises, before the launch of a first full trailer of the new IP bodes well for a strong launch of the game in advance of the feature film reboot."
Walt Disney (DIS) plans to release a new film in the science-fiction saga, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," on Dec. 18.

EA will officially unveil "Star Wars: Battlefront" at the Star Wars Celebration fan festival, which runs April 16-19 at the Anaheim Convention Center, which is located across from Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.
RELATED:
Nintendo's Zelda works magic on video game sales
